name:
The following is a transcript of a conversation between the two famous neuroscientists Dr. Buzsaki and Dr. Marder. Dr. Buzsaki's primary interests is 'neural syntax', i.e., how segmentation of neural information is organized by the numerous brain rhythms to support cognitive functions. Dr. Marder studies the dynamics of small neuronal networks, and her work was instrumental in demonstrating that neuronal circuits are not 'hard-wired' but can be reconfigured by neuromodulatory neurons and substances to produce a variety of outputs. The following is a transcript from a public academic panel discussion between the two.
-BEGIN TRANSCRIPT-

children.name: Dr. B: 'What is the primary function of the brain?'
Dr. M:'To keep the body alive.'
Dr. B:'To do cognitive work?'

Dr. M:'That's a good question. It's a good question, because one of the things that we've discovered in recent years is that the brain is doing all sorts of different things. And we understand now that the brain is really working, I think, in many different ways. So if you ask, 'How is the brain important? What is it?' and I like to say, because I think you need to think about that question, it's important for evolution.'
Dr. B:'I'm interested in your evolutionary hypothesis. How does that work?'

Dr. M:'Well, we're not evolutionists. I'm an evolutionary biologist, and my hypothesis is that our brains evolved to be small because we lived small and we lived with other species and we had to compete for food.'
Dr. B:'Okay. I'm sorry, it's been a long day. You said 'evolution'. I can guess what you're talking about, but I'm not sure what 'evolution' means. Can you explain what you mean by 'evolution'?'
Dr. M:'I'm interested more in my brain, because my brain was a problem.'
Dr. B:'What's your model of the brain?'
Dr. M:'The model that keeps the body alive, that's important because that's what we study, is the model that we study that lets us have thoughts and feelings and sensations.'

Dr. B:'But that is the primary function, and it's what we study too, and I've already been talking with the head of the neurosurgery department here at the University of Virginia who gave me some sense of how your models of the brain, especially your models of the cortex, don't fit into his. So what's your model of neurobiology?'
Dr. M:'To think'. We all know we can think. We can all do things. But, what the brain does is to allow us to think.'

Dr. B:'But what do you mean by thinking? We humans have many intellectual capabilities, but I don't think you can give me a precise definition of the word "thinking" that describes how these capabilities come into existence. This is a matter for philosophy.'
Dr. B:'No, what is the brain doing?'
Dr. M:'It is allowing us to think. But, how it allows us to think is the issue.'

Dr. B:'I mean, if you are going to explain the brain, you have to go beyond allowing us to think, and tell us what the brain is doing. Otherwise you are saying nothing. You just have a magical explanation. That's like saying the brain is allowed to do things but not allowed to do what it's doing. What's allowed is thinking, but not thinking. Why?'
Dr. M:'Well, that's right. And so, what we're trying to figure out is how the brain allows you to think. How the brain lets you know how to think.'
Dr. B:'But, what is the purpose of thinking? What's allowed, what's not allowed?'
Dr. M:'It is creating a system in which the neurons that it uses have specific functions. The function is not so much 'what does it do?'
Dr. B:'What are the basic properties of the neural network that is implemented in the brain?'
Dr. B:'I understand that what you are saying is that we all are cognitive systems, but we use neural circuitry to achieve specific cognitive goals.'
Dr. M:'It is generating the mental machinery that allows us to see the world in terms of information.'
Dr. M:'The brain allows us to be conscious. That's the most important function.'
Dr. B:'But you've just said that the brain has another function, so that it must be doing something besides allowing us to be conscious.'

Dr. M:'No, no, no, you've misunderstood me.' You know, that's why we're here is not to discuss what we should know, but what we don't know. Our brains were made to solve problems. I mean, to survive. So, we're very lucky that brains evolved and evolved in the way that it evolved. We've evolved to solve problems. To know how to find food. To know how the immune system works. To know how water works.'

Dr. B:'So, in other words, your brain is a special case of a general mechanism that allowed us to solve the problem of survival, even if we don't know what it does, because that's what we had to do. And you think that the brain, having solved this problem, is now doing something else. What's the point of that?'

Dr. M:'The brain is creating new neurons to be created and then to be modified.' That's the whole brain doing. That's it. That's the brain doing. It's not doing anything else, it's not doing anything beyond that. I mean, the brain is creating a new brain. The brain is creating a brain that can think. And then we have neurons, and then we have circuit neurons that can modify the brain. The brain, by itself, can't think.'
Dr. B:'But it has to start somewhere, right?'
Dr. B:'Are you sure the brain is doing that, because that seems a lot harder than just thinking? Wouldn't you say it's an organ of perception and thought?'
Dr. M:'What's your primary function?'

Dr. B:'Well, I can think of many things it does – like make plans, make decisions, maintain social relationships, communicate thoughts and feelings, perform language tasks, produce music, and so on. But my primary function is to make plans, make choices, make decisions, and do language and social work.'
Dr. M:'But how does that all come together? How does the planning come about?'

Dr. B:'I suppose I can say it's by virtue of the fact that I have a little sub-cortex in my brain that processes language and social information, that integrates these two features of my personality.'
Dr. M:'Right, but how do you know that this is important to you as a human being?'

Dr. B:'I'm a neuroscientist, and my primary function is to study the neural dynamics underlying learning, perception, perception of motion, the generation of motor output, and other phenomena. My primary interests are how learning takes place in small networks and in larger areas, and how the brain moves in relation to a body and to the environment.'

Dr. M:'And so your brain is, really, a toolbox of sorts, for moving about, and for perceiving, and learning, and performing many different kinds of cognitive functions, such as perception. So, really, your brain is a toolbox, and it's a toolbox that is organized so that you can move through life, and perform those different kinds of functions that are required in life, so that you can, as an animal, be able to function correctly and adapt.'

Dr. B:'It doesn't mean that the tools in the toolbox all have the same function, so that everything that you do, or everything that you learn, has to fit into one neat toolbox. You've got all this machinery built into your brain for moving in the world.'

Dr. M:'Right, right, right. Right, so your brain has, basically, a series of switches that you can manipulate to make your brain work in a certain way. So, you can turn these switches off, but you can also turn them on. You can turn on those switches and make your brain work, or work, or work in certain ways.'

Dr. M:'Well, if we ask the question, you mean 'what is the primary function'? Or the primary function? I mean, to some extent there's going to be a 'primary function'. You know, the function of the heart is to pump blood, the function of blood is to carry oxygen, the function of oxygen is to, in turn, supply our brains with oxygen.'
Dr. B:'Oh, sure. I mean, we know that the brain produces blood, and blood pumps oxygen and energy to our brains and that we're ultimately, at a certain point, an oxygen-energy system.'
Dr. B:'Hmm. I'm not sure I understand you. So your brain's role is to produce the right internal conditions to enable you to produce oxygen, right?'
Dr. M:'Correct. And this is one of the big issues, because it's a fact that our brain does not require oxygen to live. So you know, we're not getting our brains filled with enough oxygen to live.'
Dr. B:'But how can the brain be the source of the brain-stuff that is oxygen? Why don't we just run an oxygen-generator that turns air into the brain's exact oxygen content?'

Dr. M:'Exactly. That's what you're asking the questions, that's what you're describing. The answers are going to be, well, we need to be in a particular state of mind to be able to respond to that stimulus that comes from the external world, because that stimulus comes in, in a complex, convoluted way.'

Dr. M:'I mean, you do run an oxygen-generation system, but the brain's function is to make you able to think, and think and read and write and interact with people and so forth. So to me the brain has multiple functions. The brain has a primary function of making you function, and that primary function requires that you have adequate oxygen.'
Dr. B:'So if you were to cut off all air supply to the brain, what is the brain doing?'
Dr. M:'To extract meaning from sensory inputs.'
Dr. B:'Is that an algorithmic process? Is there some way of describing the algorithm? I can't even say what it is that the brain does; I can only observe how it does it.'
Dr. M:' I think it's twofold. One is to be robust to changes in temperature.'
Dr. B:' And the second?'

Dr. M:' One is to make you be who you are. But I think the primary function of being robust to changes in the external environment, like temperature and humidity is probably the main function of the brain.'

Dr. B:' But that is because the brain does a large amount of processing about the environment, and there is an evolved adaptation to do so. You would say that the brain does not do so much 'who you are' as it does 'what you are'. You would say that this is more fundamental than mere environmental adaptation.'

Dr. M:' Absolutely. But also I think it's more important than anything else, because you want to be who you are, and you want to be yourself. You want to experience the world, and you want experiences that will change you, that will change you.'
Dr. M:' Oh, yes. I think it's fundamental, because we're all the same. But you're right.'
Dr. B:' I'm trying to imagine what it would mean for something to do with who you are, and yet do nothing at all with the environment.'
Dr. M:' That would be really difficult.'

Dr. B:' You see what I mean? I'm not talking about "What makes someone like you?". I'm talking about "What would be a brain's fundamental function that is more fundamental than the brain being an environment processor, which has nothing to do with the brain being robust to temperature and humidity changes and so on?" How could a brain have a purpose which is more fundamental than that? How could a brain possibly do anything but what it is in some sense 'to do'?'

Dr. M:' Right, right. Right. Because if it's robust to change, that means that there is some sort of mechanism that can change the circuit. And so I think the first question is the mechanism of the change. The mechanism that lets the brain go from being robust to being robust to temperature, to humidity, and yet it can be robust to all kinds of changes in the external world.'

Dr. M:' That sounds weird, and maybe it's a good thing that you're saying, but I'm trying to say, because I think when I hear that, my mind goes back to the idea that there is something to be said about the environment that the brain has evolved to survive and to function in. I mean, if we're going to talk about environmental adaptation, I guess it might be better to talk about evolution than evolution of behavior.'
Dr. B:' But there's a very fundamental difference between being robust to changes in temperatures and being robust to changes at higher levels of organization, such as changes in our environment.'

Dr. M:'I can tell you two functions of the brain: one is sensory perception, and the other is cognition, the ability to understand what you are doing. So if you take perception as a metaphor, you could say that perception is something like your immediate ability to get your senses and look around. But cognition is more complicated.'
Dr. B:'Then what do you do with the sensory information that goes into the brain? How do you convert sensory information into something useful to you?'

Dr. M:'Well, if you were talking about animals, you would look at the sensory information, which goes into the brain. But we study the brain, so we look at what the brain does. But basically, you convert sensory information, whether it is visual or acoustic or olfactory, into cognitive output.'
Dr. B:'Do you understand the idea of a "representation"? And are there different types of "representations"?'
Dr. M:'Oh, it's a great question.'
Dr. B:'Well, I suppose the obvious answer is: it's the organ for making decisions.'
Dr. M:'So, if we don't decide whether it's hot or cold outside, if you don't feed your dog, it's going to die. So, the primary function is to control and feed the dog.'

Dr. B:'Ah, but in order for a brain to decide whether it's warm or cold, and feed the dog, it needs to perform a certain series of operations, right? So the brain is not really only a simple controller; it's also a computer.'
Dr. M:'The brain is the center of consciousness'.'
Dr. B:'Ah, I mean the primary function in the sense of the "ultimate end" of the system, not the "primary goal" or something.'
Dr. M:'So then you're talking about consciousness itself.'

Dr. B:'... I mean, if we have to make a distinction between "brain" and "consciousness" I don't know that there's a very well-specified boundary around what you mean by "brain" and what you mean by consciousness. I mean, it may be obvious that if there is a very large volume of space, like the volume of all neurons in a human brain, then that is just one very small dot in the space of possible brains.'
Dr. M:'Right.'
Dr. B:'The same way that the sky is a little dot of the infinite space of possible skies.'
Dr. M:'Sure.'

Dr. B:'We may have to admit that the brain's organization does not map on to the structure of reality. That is, there is no set of operations that can be performed in the brain that will duplicate all of reality, and it may seem obvious that this is just a fact. For the sake of argument, let's put this aside and assume that we have such a set of operations that is equivalent to reality.'
Dr. B:'So then what is the primary function that we're talking about?'
Dr. B:'I think you are saying that "consciousness" is the primary function?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, that is what I am saying, because, when you wake up in the morning, that is a fact, it is not a guess'.'
Dr. B:'That's not really right either.'
Dr. M:'It's the center of the nervous system'.'

Dr. B:'Where are the axons going that leave the brain and go to the spinal cord? Where are the axons that leave the spinal cord and go to the motor neurons? You can't be a neurologist without knowing about the axon, the axon pathway, the neurite. You can't be sure that there's no axon in a region of a brain until you see an axon in a particular region of a brain.'
Dr. M:'So, the first question I'm asking is why the nervous system exists at all. Why do we need neurons and the neuromodulators? How does neuronal diversity help a nervous system?'

Dr. B:'Because neurons are the fundamental units of nervous processing. Neurons operate independently of their environment, and they don't need a continuous supply of raw materials. Furthermore, they have the unique ability to communicate signals with each other – in just the way that information-processing systems are optimized to communicate with each other.'

Dr. M:'And we find that there's some other things that they do that are independent of their activity, that we wouldn't necessarily want them to do in every case, like if they are just sitting there. So, for example, neurons have to make sure that the sodium and potassium currents are appropriately balanced and regulated so they're not doing too much excitation, and that they're maintaining a constant temperature, and that they get the energy they need.'
Dr. M:'It is, it is.'
Dr. M:'That's what they say in movies about how it works, it's not actually the center of consciousness.'
Dr. B:'Why should it be, then?'
Dr. M:'It's the center of consciousness because it's a generator of consciousness, it's a generator.'

Dr. M:'Well, the primary function is sensory processing. And then, of course, motor processing. And the primary function of all neurons is just to do the biological processes that are required for their function. And I think for the most part, most of us, when we start studying the brain we think, well, we might study sensory processing because maybe it's the best understood. Maybe it's the easiest to understand.'
Dr. B:'That's not the answer.'
Dr. M:'No, but that's not why we study the brain, that's why we study the nervous system. Because we think that the brain is an organ, that has evolved to provide specific biological functions.'
Dr. B:'I don't mean that. I mean, what is the primary function?'

Dr. M:'The primary function is sensory and motor function'. That's how it works. And the secondary function is sensory and executive function'. That's what it does. And the primary function is to feed all this stuff back to the system and to tell it what to do.'
Dr. B:'Let's talk about how the brain's primary function of sensory and motor function is organized within the brain and how it is wired into the environment'.'
Dr. M:'OK.'
Dr. B:'What is the organization of the cortex that leads to this division of labor? How is the functional integration of the various parts of the cortex organized?'

Dr. M:'You know, I think that in theory the functional integration of these different neurons could be very chaotic.' You know, because if we are talking about neurons that were, say, very highly regulated, highly controlled units, you know, and, and and they were, you know, they were firing their own synaptic currents, if their receptors were different, or their axons were different. It's possible that these neurons could be, you know, you could, could be independent of each other.'

Dr. B:'And this is an integral property of the brain, and I'm talking about the primary structure of the brain as opposed to the wiring and organization of individual parts. We are trying to figure out how these cells are wired together to make up the whole brain.'

Dr. M:'So, I've spent a lot of my life talking to people who believe that the only function of the brain is feeding information back to the rest of the system. So, you know, the brain is a black box. We don't know anything about how it works. You know, and it just tells you how to do stuff.'

Dr. M:'It is of course for cognition. For cognition, for perception, for action, for emotion, for memory, for thinking. So, it is of course for thinking. But why study brain? Why study brain, because it is of course, because as we start thinking, we start doing things and we can also ask, and this is an important thing, we can ask why we should study brain. But why should we study brain because it's of course, because we think.'
Dr. B:'Right.'
Dr. M:'We think because we think.'
Dr. M:'So we think, we think, we are thinking. So it is of course not only thinking, but thinking.'
Dr. B:'How do you think we think?'

Dr. M:'Why should we think? Well, what is it that we think about? Why should we think? We think about other people. Why should we think about other people? Why should we know what people are thinking about?'
Dr. B:'But—you're talking about the higher-order cortex, or the cortex of higher organization. So what is its function? It is obviously something that we should not think about without knowing it.'

Dr. M:'We should be curious. We should be curious. So, that's why it is not that the brain, the brain does all the functions. We should be excited that we have a brain. So, the primary function of a brain is to be curious. So you want to look at the brain to ask why should we study the brain? Because of course, for cognition, for perception... For perception we use our brain, and for action, for action, our brain is important.'

Dr. B:'So you're saying that when we think we need to study the brain because the brain has some function, that function is not cognition or perception, but curiosity. How do we know that? What's your definition of curiosity?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, and this is not that you don't have to be curious about things that are important for society. Like when you are walking in the street and you don't know who someone is. Like for example, if you're in a restaurant and you see somebody and you don't recognize them you should not automatically be curious about who they are because it is a potential threat to you. And we should ask, should we be curious about people in restaurants and ask 'Who are you?'

Dr. B:'Are you saying that this is not curiosity? That this is some sort of special exception, and it has nothing to do with curiosity? If that were the case, I'd like to be told what this new cognitive function of curiosity is. Like what does curiosity have to do with cognition? What does it mean to be curious? How does it work in practice? I'm also a bit confused by your notion that 'the primary function of a "brain" is to be curious'.'

Dr. M:'So, you think 'the primary function'... Let me see if I understand your thinking. Because you're talking about the brain, and it's easy to confuse people, because of course they think 'well you know, the primary function or the primary function of your brain is to think.'
Dr. B:'Okay, but your brain's response to curiosity is not always cognition, right? And if curiosity has some function other than cognition, then what is it? It's just curiosity, I suppose?'
Dr. M:'Sure, and the response is, it is a mix of curiosity and cognition. Because we use our brain when we ask questions, when we ask 'what is that?'

Dr. B:'Right, so it's not really an issue of the brain's 'cognitive architecture' or something like that. We have a brain that works to answer questions. That's why I keep asking you what it means to be curious, and your answer keeps turning out to be 'no'. This is an issue of the actual architecture of your brain. This is not the issue of the question.'
Dr. M:'That's right.'

Dr. B:'So, the primary function of our brains is just to think, and we can study brains because it's obviously a way of asking why we should think? Because thinking is obviously part of our higher-order goals?'

Dr. M:'Right. The brain is like a processor, a processor that processes a very large number of inputs from neurons. And that is important because it's very easy to ask why should we do neuroscience, because we might want to study the brain because we are interested in cognition.'
Dr. B:'Why is the brain part of our higher order goals? How do we know that thinking is part of our higher goals?'
Dr. B:'I'm not so sure that studying brain is justifiable, because you are not doing anything that can't be done in a much better way, say, by modeling it in software. So what will it tell us?'

Dr. M:'Right, so the reason to study brain is to ask questions that cannot be asked about any other organ in the body. So, so that would tell you that we should study brain because we want to understand how the brain works. But the reason for studying brain is to understand how the mind works and then maybe you could use that knowledge to design new brain implants that could help people think better.'

Dr. B:'So you would expect that you would have already solved the problem of how to make human beings think better by modeling their brains, if you had started out doing things in your field that weren't of the type that could be done in software, such as designing a brain implant that improves performance of a cognitive task. You would expect this, correct?'

Dr. M:'So if we had the ability to solve all of these problems, and if we had the capability to design brain implants, why study brain, study brain, because you know, what you would expect to learn by doing, if you think about the brain. That's exactly why we study brain because we know that all of the other organs and organs in the body, you know, the skin is also very important for what we call cognition because cognition is also perception.'

Dr. B:'Are you actually saying that it's better to do research on brains that is of a different kind than research on all the other organs that make up a human body, because it would be easier to do research on the brain? There are lots of other organs in the body that are also involved in cognition, and you know that, right? So why study brains that are not only involved in cognition but also very different from organs that are involved in cognition?'

Dr. M:'What is the primary role of the brain?' I'm thinking there are many functions of the brain. The brain is one of those organs that has many roles. But one of the roles of the brain is to extract information from the environment, and the brain is the brain is the best environment for extracting information from the environment. The other function of the brain is the transmission of information. So the primary function of brain is to extract useful information from the environment to provide for the needs of the brain.'
Dr. B:'Hmm, I don't quite see how this could be answered by neuroscience.'

Dr. M:'Because what we are doing is studying neurons, and brain cells. And the primary function of a neuron is to pass information from one side of the cell body to the other side. The primary function of brain cells is to pass information through the synaptic network and the neuromodulatory networks, so to produce useful information and to provide for the function of the brain. I think that is really the primary function of this organ.'

Dr. B:'So you're saying the brain is just the organ that does the job of transmitting information? I don't think the brain can extract information. I think the brain just has to transmit information about what the brain does, so that the brain can do the job of doing the job of transmitting the information. For example, a brain that tells a brain that it is time to eat and the brain needs to eat. That's a primary function of the central nervous system.'
Dr. M:'But that's a different problem. That's a different problem.'

Dr. B:'It's one of the functions that we call "information transfer," but information transfer doesn't seem like the primary function of the brain.' (Pause.) 'Well, yes, it is. The brain has to transmit information, it has to transmit the information that tells the brain what to do. But we are talking about the brain's function as an organism in the real world. And in the real world, the brain has other functions.'

Dr. M:'I don't know. I'm not sure we'll even agree that this is a function of the brain. It could be a function of some organ. It could be intrinsic, because in principle, all information is potentially available in the environment. So how important is the need to extract information from environmental stimuli?'

Dr. B:'Well, I think that you'll never be able to give us an answer to this, because there's no one who can really speak to the issue, except maybe Aristotle. He didn't have any way to measure the intensity of sensory information that was in the environment. He didn't know what the eye was doing, so it was no wonder that he didn't understand it.'
Dr. M:'But he had a theory of it, and I'm sure Aristotle had a theory of many functions of the mind and body.'
Dr. M:'Well, I mean, I don't even see how this could arise out of neuroscience, how can you answer a question that you don't really know?'

Dr. B:'I mean, if you had a superintelligence built of neurons, you could probably learn some useful things about how they work, like that they're sensitive to the size of the population of synapses, that they fire, that they use more and more synapses as you increase the population of synapse inputs, etc.'

Dr. M:'The primary function is cognition. It's processing information. It's recognizing patterns of activity and then generating action potentials, or other kinds of firing patterns. But there are two functions that are really important. One is sensory-motor transformation. When we experience a stimulus, it generates a pattern of firing from neurons that can move us, that can generate motor movements, and that can allow us to take action.'

Dr. B:'Let's take a moment to review this. The brain does seem to have multiple layers of processing. There are input layers and output layers, and there are intermediate layers. Now, the brain has been organized in such a way that these layers of processing are connected to each other. How do you explain that?'

Dr. M:'Well, if you ask a cell biologist like myself, the answer is going to be complicated, because the brain has hundreds of cells, and each cell has dozens of distinct cell-type-specific properties. And so to have multiple levels of neurons that are connected to each cell is going to be difficult, because you have to understand the properties of the cell type, and then you're going to be worried about maintaining the properties of the neurons, and how they interact.'
Dr. B:'So the brain is a complex network of interacting cell types. You can think of each layer as a network of neurons, with different properties. This is a good idea, isn't it?'

Dr. M:'So the brain, as we have understood it, has multiple distinct networks, and the networks are connected, but they're not strictly linear. They're kind of a spider web of interacting networks, so that when you're taking this out of the biological realm, the networks are going to be very complicated.'

Dr. M:'A brain is an electrical circuit, or it's a network of neurons, which has many parallel circuit loops. Some of those loops, like the stomatogastric circuit that is involved in chewing, are fairly obvious, and some of the networks are less obvious. But every circuit has its own characteristics, and every circuit is designed to perform a specific task, as an adaptive circuit. So in some ways it's a bit like assembling a circuit.'

Dr. B:'But if the brain is an electrical network, then it can't have layers of processing. At the point of being processed, a neural pattern is either "fired" or not fired. Why would you want to have separate processing circuits for different tasks?'
Dr. M:'One function is the generation of consciousness.'

Dr. M:'Oh, I'd say it's getting us to breathe. The primary function of the nervous system is to make sure that you survive, right? The primary function of your brain is to make sure you survive. And then, also, you think you might want to have a life, you might want to do things, you might want... I think you might want a home, I think you might need a home, I'm not sure what you're asking. You might want to have kids.'

Dr. B:'Um... no. I have a son, and I don't know if he'd like that. I'm looking for a way to get more control over how he develops. It's been interesting in the past how that control aspect is very difficult to get, and I'm not sure it's gotten easier over time.'

Dr. M:'I mean, the first time I thought about this was when we had this mouse, and this mouse had a tumor. And the tumor was growing. And we had to kill it and you know we had to kill the mouse, and I didn't know what I thought about what the function of the brain was. I mean, the function of the neuron is getting enough sodium, right? Like how do you add sodium to the neuron? How does it work?'
Dr. B:'Well, the brain has to make decisions, it's got to make plans, it has to choose courses of action.'
Dr. M:'So, the primary function of brains is to encode the nervous system.'
Dr. M:'You know, we don't know what the brain is doing all the time and it's often thought that it's like being asleep all the time, so the first thing is you know, what's it awake for?'
Dr. B:'How about the fact that your daughter is blind? Do you think this affects your ability to see in general?'

Dr. M:'So if you want to answer your question that the primary function of brain is seeing what you need to see? It's got all kinds of other functions that we don't yet understand, but you know, I mean, we don't really know the brain is working all the time because we've never seen what the brain is going to do when it is awake.'
Dr. B:'What do you do when you are awake?'
Dr. M:'I'm not awake when I'm working.'
Dr. B:'You're not awake when you're sleeping.'
Dr. B:'Then why don't you tell me what your theory says about what the brain is awake for?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, well, it's not that we've written a theory and we're going to put it in a paper today, but, we really don't know that much about it.'

Dr. M:'But I would answer your question by saying that my theory would say that the brain is awake to keep the body working for your life. Right? Because if the brain were asleep, if the brain were not working, the body would stop working. So, I mean, I mean, that's the simplest answer I can give you.'

Dr. B:'Okay, I'm confused. I would answer your answer by asking what the theory predicts about what the brain does when it is awake. What does the theory say about the brain being awake when my daughter is blind?'
Dr. M:'It is certainly the most complex part of the body, and probably, most critical for our survival.'
Dr. B:'But what is it? I think I would like some more precise answer.'

Dr. M:'I know you would because it is interesting because you are asking us to find an answer that you think is simple. The reality is that the brain contains the whole set of mechanisms that allows us to perceive, to use sensory organs, to move, to think, to reason, to behave. All of these things require circuits with neurons that can interact. The brain has evolved to be the most complex thing in the body and it does need to be flexible. It can't be fixed and frozen.'
Dr. B:'Ah, but is that just a metaphor, or does the brain have a specific purpose?'

Dr. M:'Absolutely. We were very interested that you are asking us because it is interesting, if I can find a metaphor, or find an analogy, for what I think of as brain circuits, which are very complex and flexible, so that I can tell you what some of our projects are working on. I mean, a lot of you are very interested in finding circuits that produce specific behaviors. Some of our projects are interested in understanding the circuits that produce behaviors such as sleep.'

Dr. B:'The neural circuits for vision, for hearing, for locomotion, for cognition and for motivation. I'm not interested in the circuits that produce behavior such as being hungry or dreaming. I'm interested in the circuitry for producing the behavior of being conscious.'
Dr. B:'So what is the most important aspect of brain functioning?'
Dr. M:'I'm going to ask that. What is the primary function or, the primary function of your brain?'

Dr. B:'Well, as we all know, the brain is a higher-level processing system than our eyes, so we can't expect the primary function of our brains to be a detailed analysis of the images being projected onto our retinas by our visual cortex. I mean, we do, of course, see the output of the brain, which is the perception of the outside world, but that is more of a peripheral phenomenon, right?'

Dr. M:'No, that peripheral phenomenon, and this is what I'm interested in. So, you're asking if the primary function of brains is to sort and to organize information in a way that enables us to think, right? That enables you to think. The primary function of brains, and then the brains of all of us, is to sort information in a way and to organize it, to make sense of it. To enable you to think.'
Dr. B:'In the course of living, the brain serves as a sensory organ to perceive the world, to carry out motor activities, and in particular, it performs high-level sensory-motor integration.'
Dr. M:'Okay, and now when you say high-level sensory integration, how does the brain do that?'
Dr. B:'You mean the integration of all the pieces of information that come in from various parts of the world, to form a unified representation of the situation being faced?'
Dr. M:'OK, but, I'm going to say you are wrong because your brain isn't just a sensory organ.'
Dr. B:'Why do you say that?'
Dr. M:'Because the brain also controls our behavior, and behavior requires coordination, and therefore, it's also required for sensory-motor coordination.'
Dr. B:'It's a higher-level organ, but I suppose you are right that the brain isn't just the organ of sense.'
Dr. M:'Right, but so that the brain is, the highest-level organ, right?'

Dr. B:'Well, I wouldn't say that, and I'd say that the brain has a whole bunch of other important functions that it doesn't do that we know of. I mean, it's not just that your brain is able to perceive the world. It's not just that the brain has some ability to execute the movement of your fingers. It's that your brain has a much higher-level capability to carry out the motion of your fingers without the input coming in from the eyes.'

Dr. M:'Well, that makes sense. You'd want to separate out the, the, you know, the, how does the brain control the motion of the fingers without input from the eyes.' So it's a much bigger system. But your brain is more than just a sensory organ, and you know you're very good at what you do. You're very good at figuring out how the brain works in the world. So you're an expert in that. You're very skilled in that.'
Dr. B:'I would say that it's to create an internal narrative of experience, and to use it to predict and control reality.'

Dr. M:'So, I think I'm going to say 'it's to create an experience', but it's to create a narrative or, a narrative of experience that is consistent with what you want, and then you can use it to control the world.' I'm just trying to figure out. I think that you're saying it's to control reality, is that what you're saying?'

Dr. M:'I've always been fascinated with understanding how the brain works, how the brain processes information. How information gets into the brain, how information gets into the system, the neural circuit, the circuits that are there, how circuits work together. The brain, in itself, is quite interesting. It's got the nervous system, and it's got all these different motor and sensory systems that come together.'

Dr. B:'But it's not quite a purely neural system. The brain isn't just a collection of neurons and synaptic connections. It's got a cerebrospinal fluid system, an immune system, and some other stuff.'
Dr. M:'Yeah. It has muscles, and so does the body.'
Dr. B:'It has muscles, but it's not exactly the same muscles that move the world. How does the brain know that's what it's doing?'

Dr. M:'So, the primary function of your brain is to make sense of sensory information that comes through your ears, your eyes, your nose, and your mouth. How does your brain know what your eyes are seeing, what your nose is smelling, what your ears are hearing?'

Dr. B:'Well, the eyes, nose, and ears all have different neural circuitry, so the brain is getting information about their functions from elsewhere. It's not a one-to-one mapping, but your brain has many distinct and separate neural circuitry circuits for eyes, nose, ears, and so on.'
Dr. M:'Oh yeah. It's got its own muscles.'
Dr. M:'You can't tell a person their primary function without knowing their history.'
Dr. B:'That's what I mean by "knowing your history". What do you think your brain does, and why?'
Dr. M:'It has to have all the things that you need for your life.'

Dr. B:'Let me give an example. When I was studying neuroscience, I did some work with animals in which the animal's visual cortex was cut in half along a sagittal plane, and the animals' ability to see objects and navigate the world was impaired as the result.'
Dr. M:'Wow, that sounds like a real problem, that's a real problem that you're talking about!'
Dr. B:'Yeah. The problem with this experiment was that the animals had to learn to navigate using their two visual fields. I've never seen anything like that ever.'
Dr. M:'But we have.'
Dr. M:'I don't know what my brain is doing, really.'
Dr. B:'Well, you're not going to get far on a job where you don't even know your own specialty.'
Dr. B:'What did you think the brain was doing the last time it was doing it?'
Dr. M:'Well, my brain is a brain for cognition, for thinking.'
Dr. B:'What do you mean by history?'

Dr. M:'Well, they were always eating; or they were always walking; or they were learning to read, or they were talking, or they were writing poetry; or they were talking about science, or they were doing art, or they were making music.'

Dr. M:'I think the brain is a pretty complex circuit, as you say, in terms of how neurons are interacting to produce a circuit, but one of the most important functions, I think, of the brain is to generate behavior, and also to generate all of the functions of cognition, which is the ability to think and to reason.'
Dr. B:'I agree. Now, what is the primary function for a human brain?'
Dr. M:'The primary function is to acquire new knowledge and to use it to inform our actions.'
Dr. B:'What do you mean by 'use it to inform our action'? Is it like the brain is in control of everything we do?'
Dr. M:'Yes, it controls the actions of everything that we do'.'
Dr. M:'No, the brain has to be able to respond to the demands of the world and the tasks we have to do every day.'

Dr. B:'Then you're saying the brain is a mind. But if we're talking about the brain doing something other than just acquiring new knowledge and using it to inform our daily activities, then what is it that we are talking about?'

Dr. M:'I suppose that in the most general terms, we are talking about an information processor, because you've got to have information to be a mind and be smart and not make mistakes and also have to be flexible. Right?'
Dr. M:'No, we need to use it for our personal gain, to inform our actions, because it's our actions that change the world.'
Dr. B:'You say you need to use the brain to help people's actions change the world, and this is what the brain does. So it's really the brain that's doing it, right?'
Dr. M:'It is to provide the animal with sensory and motor input, so that it can feed, move, and protect itself.'
Dr. B:'But you cannot make a snake into a dog. We have to ask what is the brain doing when we make a dog. This is a very important question, and it is also not a trivial one.'
Dr. M:'How does the brain learn? How is it evolving?'
Dr. M:'Well the problem is we think we are putting everything together into this thing called a brain, and you have to remember the brain doesn't just put things together.'

Dr. M:'This is why we have evolved the concept of a cortex, a secondary brain, that is able to understand and process information that has not been directly encoded by the genome, that is, that has been encoded in the activity of neurons. This cortex enables us to think about how we are feeling, to think about our health, to think about how to make better machines, and to think about things like that.'

Dr. B:'You are trying to explain the dog's behavior by describing the workings of a higher-order-brain structure. But this is like describing a building's structure in terms of the way it moves air and water; yet when we try to use air and water to describe the building's behavior we end up with all sorts of difficulties. You're using the wrong model to describe the dog.'
Dr. M:'Right, well, because we are not looking at the genome. We are looking at how the brain works, and that is why we have this new set of neurons that are called neurons of higher-order-brains.'
Dr. B:'What is a higher-order brain? Does it use the same material as the cortex, or is it a separate structure?'

Dr. M:'No, this is a separate structure, and this is important because in order to understand the cortex properly we have to understand the brain. Because the brain does not behave in the way the lower-order-brain should. The lower-order-brain has no capacity to understand, to think about the meaning of emotion, to understand how we are feeling and what is going on.'
Dr. B:'Where did it come from? How did it get there?'

Dr. M:'It has come from evolution, it has come from evolution. And we know, for example, that we know that there are other primates in our world that have brains with large numbers of neurons that are not sensory neurons. We know that there are animals that have brains with far greater numbers of neurons, and yet they have less sensory neurons. They have less number of neurons than we do.'

Dr. B:'No, we are looking at the whole dog, and trying to explain what is going on in its head. We have no way to use air and waves to describe a dog's internal state of mind. You are only imagining things.'

Dr. M:'But we have a way to describe the dog's behaviors, and then we use that to look at what is going on internally. For example, when we watch a dog's behavior and we ask ourselves, well, what is going on inside that dog's head, we are looking for a signal, a sign. This signal might say something about how healthy the dog is, but it might also say something about how the dog is feeling at the moment, about how the dog wants to be.'
Dr. B:'Why aren't you talking about the dog's genome? You are talking about the dog.'

Dr. M:'Okay, well, look, because we are looking at how all dogs are different. We are trying to look at how brains are different, because brains are evolving in the species. We are trying not to talk about the genome, because you are trying to figure out the genome. This is a different type of study. We are trying this in animals with a brain that is bigger and more complex.'

Dr. B:'But I am trying to explain what you are doing, what you mean by talking about what goes on in a dog's brain. What you are really talking about is what goes on in your own head. It is your own brain, after all, which is evolving in the species, not the genome.'

Dr. M:'So that is a good question, and it is one I often get asked. So that has been something we have studied. But, I think as neuroscientists, the most important function is to think about how all that activity in the brain is organized. The second is to understand what all those neurons do, how they are built, how they are configured.'
Dr. B:'Ah, but I'm not a neuroscientist—I'm just a brain-computer researcher. So what are the primary functions of the brain as I understand them?'

Dr. M:'The brain is a very mysterious thing. In some sense it seems like the most mysterious part of the nervous system because its circuits are the most complicated. But we don't know the function of each neuron.'

Dr. M:'The brain has the fundamental job of protecting the nervous system. It's the hub of information. It's the interface to the outside. It's the circuit that connects neurons together, and all of those functions are critically important in ensuring that we do not succumb to pathogens, that we do not have brain damage, that we are not too hot or cold. So, the brain has to perform all of these very, very, very important functions. What is the primary function?'
Dr. B:'To do calculations.'

Dr. M:'To do calculations, right? So we do calculations, we do arithmetic and we do calculus and we do calculus on the fly. So we are doing calculations all of the time. We're always calculating. And it's interesting to watch, when you see someone doing arithmetic, when they're doing math, when they're trying to solve a problem. So, a mathematician often will write down a formula that will look like, oh, what would be the differential equations that would solve this problem?'
Dr. B:'Uh huh.'

Dr. M:'Well, because they're trying to find a formula that's elegant, that will be simple. But I mean, the reality is, most of the time in the course of solving these problems, you are doing a calculation. So you're doing calculations all of time, all of time. You're writing equations, and so and you're trying to find, you're trying to understand these equations. So it's to understand the rules and the laws of the world.'
Dr. B:'Oh, this is math, right. What's the point of asking?'
Dr. B:'Yes, this is a good point. So in the world, what are we doing? We're doing arithmetic, right?'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. B:'We're calculating stuff. What's that got to do with the outside world? What does that have to do with the world around us?'
Dr. M:'Right.'
Dr. B:'The primary function is a very important one. The primary function is the ability to reason.'
Dr. M:'Reasoning.'

Dr. B:'I mean, we're not talking about just any type of reasoning, just the fact that we think of certain things, we take certain actions based on our beliefs. What's going on in the brain that allows us to reason like that? What are the principles by which we think of the world?'
Dr. B:'To maintain a stable body, which is something we all have in common, of course.'
Dr. M:'Yes, of course.'

Dr. B:'You said "the brain has the fundamental, core job of protecting the neuronal system", but I think the brain has another, more fundamental function; that it organizes, synthesizes, and communicates information. So it has an important role in many different levels of organization, including a role in cognition. We, ourselves, are "made of brain". Therefore we need brains.'
Dr. M:'We are brain-like.'
Dr. B:'And we, ourselves, are made of brain. So it follows that we, too, have brains.'
Dr. M:'Which are the brains of the brain?' The only brain, the brain of the brain. Which is the most fundamental and the primary brain? I think it's the brain of the whole brain. The core.'

Dr. B:'No. If we are the brains of other brains, then we are the brains  of the brains of the brains. If we are not brains of other brains—if we are brains of our own—then we are brains of the brains of our brains.'
Dr. M:'Right.'
Dr. B:'No, the core is not the most fundamental. It's the brain of brains. If you are thinking of a large brain, like a human brain, then that is the brain of brains.'

Dr. M:'Okay, and so then how much of the brain can you take with you when you jump out the window? Because I thought we were leaving these ideas behind. I thought this was going to be science, not philosophy.'

Dr. B:'But the brain does much more than that. It organizes the entire nervous system and all its processes and relationships. It can communicate information, transmit sensory experiences, and store information about the past and the future in long-term memory. That information is stored in our brains, and we can remember it through many, many years of our lives.'

Dr. M:'So, my view is that the brain is the hub of information, and the hub of information in all mammals is the brain, the primary role of the brain is to communicate with the outside. We have sensory neurons that go to our ears, to our eyes, to our nose, to our tongue, to our muscles, and so forth, and the brain is the interface to all of those different kinds of neurons. In general, the brain is the single hub for the entire nervous system.'

Dr. B:'To maintain a certain temperature range within the body, and a certain amount of metabolism for survival. That's a very, very basic function of the brain, but it's not one that has to be explicitly thought about and controlled.'
Dr. M:'So, what are the functions that you're worried about for example when we're talking about brain damage?'
Dr. B:'I don't know what you mean by that question.'
Dr. B:'The primary function of the human brain is to maintain a healthy state of mind.'
Dr. M:'I don't know that, but it is certainly not just to store memories.'

Dr. M:'The primary function of the whole organism is to produce a conscious, functioning, individual who can behave in their environment, be conscious of their environment, learn from their environment, and make their environment better.'
Dr. M:'Well, it's not to make you think, it's not just to make you think but to control your motor systems.'
Dr. B:'No, it's to make the muscles of the body move in specific ways.'

Dr. M:'So it's not just thinking but it's moving muscles, it's not, but muscles move muscles. So, you know I thought you were asking about neural circuitry. You know, because there's some neurons that are responsible for muscle movements and there are neurons that are responsible, you know neurons that are responsible of moving the muscles of the mouth, the mouth, the brain moves muscles. So, muscles have a lot to do with the brain. There are many different muscles that contribute to chewing.'

Dr. B:'Okay, but can we talk about the brain in a little more depth, you think, or should we go back to your original topic, which is the muscles and the role of the muscles? The muscles are in the body, and the body moves. The brain has a role in movement, as does the muscles.'

Dr. M:'Well, that's a wonderful question, and I'm going to give you an answer that's going to be completely different from most of the people who have been talking about the brain.  The brain is a sensory apparatus that provides the body with feedback about how it's doing.  We have some sensory inputs, but most of our sensory input comes from our eyes, our ears, our nose, the tongue, and that's all sensory input.'
Dr. B:'What do we mean by sensory input?'

Dr. M:'You mean, we hear sound, we see light, we smell food, we taste food, and we use these sensory inputs to make decisions.  We're walking around our neighborhoods, we're trying to decide if somebody is at home, we're trying not to step in the street because it's too noisy and we're going to hit the cars or the motorcycles or the other people.'

Dr. B:'Hmm, we don't really know much about how sensory inputs are transformed into perceptual experiences, but we know that there's some organization that turns a high-level pattern of electrical activity in your brain into a low-level pattern of neural firing in the visual cortex, and that's how a visual scene is represented.'

Dr. M:'And it's a little bit like that with the auditory system, because most of the sensory systems that I studied and that I read about, they turn their sensory input into a set of motor patterns that can then move the muscles.  So in your brain, you have lots of neurons that fire in different ways.  Some of them fire in a sequential manner, some of them fire together, and it is this pattern of firing that creates the sensory experience that the brain receives from the outside world.'
Dr. B:'So what you're saying is that the brain is not the primary locus for cognition?'

Dr. M:'The brain is what we study, it's important to remember that the brain was evolved from many, many years of evolution to support behavior, cognition, and many other functions that were necessary for animals to eat, to survive in the world, and to procreate and to give us the joy of our children.'

Dr. B:'Let me turn that around. The primary function of the _cortex_ is the processing of information. We see the same thing in the visual cortex and the auditory cortex. The same part of the brain is doing the same thing. The visual cortex and the temporal cortex in the same brain. The processing of auditory information in the same brain, the temporal cortex. The integration of the visual information in the same areas of the cortex, the lateral intraparietal cortex.'

Dr. M:'The primary function of the central nervous system is to process and interpret sensory information, to generate muscle movements and motor neuron activity, to process and interpret motor neuron activity, and to provide motor neuron excitability. A secondary function of the nervous system is to produce the rhythmic behaviour that gives the animal its adaptive behaviour. So, the most basic role of the central nervous systems of animals is to extract sensory information and to convert sensory information into motor patterns and motor patterns.'

Dr. B:'It is interesting to observe the two-stage development of the neural circuits in the central nervous systems and the relationship between sensory processing and motor output. This relationship between the cerebral cortex and other regions of the brain is called the cortex. I have a couple of simple questions. First, what do you call the cortex?'

Dr. M:'This question is always asked because people don't want to be told that the brain is just for brain activity. The brain is for generating and maintaining the nervous system. What I want to tell you is that the brain has evolved to control and generate behaviour. We are not going to be interested in how many brain cycles per second. We want to be interested in controlling behaviour.'
Dr. B:'Okay, but how many brain cycles are there? What's your theory of neuropsychology? How do we know there are no higher levels of organization?'

Dr. M:'Okay, how many brain cycles? Right, I can tell you the number of brain cycles per second, but not how the brain evolved. The brain evolved to control behaviour. There are many, many different neurons and many different connections and many different pathways. The brain developed to produce behaviour, and we are going to be interested to look at how behaviour was produced by evolution.'
Dr. B:'This seems so obvious that it's hard to believe that there are any people who believe that.'
Dr. M:'So, okay, how many brain circuits are there? How many brain circuits are working at any given time?'
Dr. B:'Is that even a number?'
Dr. M:'Oh, yeah, we can count up how many brain cells and their connections are firing at any given time.'

Dr. M:'No, no higher levels of organisation, because the behaviour is defined, so that you cannot do higher levels of organisation because the brain is doing its job. It's generating the behaviour. There are only two levels of organisation that I'm interested in talking about.'
Dr. B:'What's the other level of organisation?'

Dr. M:'Well, I guess the second level of organisation is how much of the brain is used, which is to say that if we were to take all of the cells in the brain, and we were to measure the activity in all of the cells, the cells themselves would tell you which cells are the active cells. Because some cells are very quiet. In the brain, neurons are always active. Cells are always moving, because cells need to be alive.'
Dr. B:'But if we can talk about just the neural activity within a brain, we'll be better off.'

Dr. M:'Yes, we'll be much better off. The problem is, is that if you think about a neuron, a neuron has a single membrane potential, and if you think about how it gets to be the membrane potential of the neuron, there are multiple pathways that get to that membrane potential. There are synaptic connections, ion channels, and membrane currents that all contribute.'
Dr. B:'Oh, I see.'
Dr. B:'Ah, but my concern is more with the control problem. I mean, the brain is just a control system, and it is not a control system that does something. The brain is just for control.'

Dr. M:'Exactly. It is a control system that allows us to control other systems. Let's say you have a computer network and your neighbour is trying to hack into your network, and he hacks into the network for the wrong reasons. Then the entire network will be compromised and you will have to shut down the network.'

Dr. B:'And then the hacker wants to go off and do something else. Now I'm confused, because the hacker's brain is a control system as well as the network. The hacker can use the control system to shut down the whole network and go off and do what he wants to do. But then I still think that the hacker is going off and doing something other than what he's been told to do, and there must be some other control system that the hacker is controlling.'
Dr. B:'This doesn't make it a general intelligence control system. The brain has evolved for the control problem. The brain is simply a control system. What are we trying to accomplish, here?'

Dr. M:'Right, and that is the control problem. We have developed a very powerful control system. I want to say we have not created a control system that is capable of controlling all the biological systems. We have created a control system capable of controlling animals, mammals, and humans with remarkable accuracy and ability. We have built a control system that can control the behaviour of animals, but we have also constructed control systems that can control the activity of many, many neurons and can construct circuits that can control behaviour.'
Dr. B:'How is this possible?'
Dr. B:'Then I would say that the brain is not a network of control. We can't go into the brain and take out an entire control network. We can't get into the brain and rewrite it to look different.'

Dr. M:'Well, the brain is like a machine, and a control system is like a program. It is like a program that says, you know, I want to control behaviour. So, the question is, why do I want to control what I do, why should I have control of what I do?'

Dr. B:'I suppose we should be clear that the brain does not have a complete command of all the neurons in the body, but it does have the ability to control some. The brain controls the body via nerves and the nerves control the body via muscle, and this control system is optimized for the control problem, not the control problem.'

Dr. M:'Oh, I disagree, because if I want to control my body, you know, if I want to move my body, if I want my body to feed me or to drink, if I want them to move, and then to feed me and to drink, if it is too hard to control that body, then I cannot control my brain, because if I cannot control the body then my brain will starve as well. So, I want my body and my brain to be fully functional.'

Dr. B:'Your brain and body have been evolved to control your behavior, but not your brain and body, I think. We are talking about the difference between brain and brain-body and body and body. They are not the same, the brain and the brain-body and the body and the body-body. It is like asking me to control your brain, but not the brain that controls you.'

Dr. M:'It has evolved that way. The problem with control systems is they don't work perfectly well. We have to be aware that the brain has been evolved to function as a control system. Now, there is something like 2 billion neurons in the brain, and those 2 billion neurons work together. There is not something going on that is perfect; that is the problem. There is something going on in the brain that is imperfect and that needs to be monitored and worked on.'
Dr. B:'But when we're talking about this particular control system, this brain, what are we trying to do? What does it accomplish?'
Dr. B:'Oh, but the brain does a whole lot of things! How can the brain not be doing anything, when it has a whole bunch of stuff going on inside it?'

Dr. M:'So, the brain is the controller of all bodily processes and it's the controller of all behaviour.' It's also a controller of behaviour in animals with a small nervous system. So it's really two kinds of controller, it's a controller that generates appropriate behaviour, and it's a controller of the generation of appropriate behaviour.'
Dr. B:'That's what I'm getting at. I'm trying to figure out whether a brain's role is to generate behaviors or whether it's to control behavior.'
Dr. M:'I think it's both.'

Dr. B:'Well, then why did evolution choose to generate a brain with the sole purpose of executing behavior? Is there some other reason why it was good to have a brain that generates behavior, other than the fact that it generates behaviors? The brain is the controller, so it's good to have a controller that generates behavior, right? But the controller also generates the behavior? So it's also good to have a behavior-generating controller? Why not have two controllers that both generate behavior?'
Dr. B:'Are you saying that your brain acts as a central processing unit, like a supercomputer in a computer? I'm not seeing it that way.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, you're right. No, I'm talking about the central processing unit and the central processing unit is a subset of all the circuits in the brain. The central processing unit is just a subset of all of the circuits in the network that has a central processing unit. So the brain consists of a number of interconnected brain regions. These include the cortex, which has several regions, the ganglia, and the other small regions in the brain that are important.'
Dr. B:'What about the brain's role in language processing? Do you think that it's part of your central processing unit?'

Dr. M:'The brain is the primary information processor of the animal. The brain is responsible for the acquisition of data from a vast array of sensory modalities, for the manipulation of sensory data to make decisions, to make movements, to move muscles, to produce sensory feedback of activity to allow you to learn what you have to do to get the behavior you are looking for.'
Dr. B:'That's the sort of thing I wanted to ask. What is the brain doing?'

Dr. M:'It's doing things like this. We think that it's doing things like sensing, like reading facial features to determine a person's identity, and also reading things like letters, and so it has all these multiple functions.'
Dr. B:'And what is the brain doing, in the course of doing these things?'

Dr. M:'Well, I mean, you can talk about synaptic transmission and circuit stability and neural circuit function in general, but I want to talk about specific functions that the brain needs to do, because when I read some of the literature from, say, the late 20th Century on neuroanatomy and neurophysiology, I find these are fascinating little details.'
Dr. B:'I understand. Well, in terms of cognitive science, how would you summarize your work?'

Dr. M:'I am interested in how the brain works. I study the brain. I look at the brain in animals and then I study how the brain behaves in people, and we use these models of brain activity and try to understand how it changes over time in response to environmental changes. And how the brain responds to other changes as well. And so that is what I study. That is the primary thing I study. And it has a lot to do with understanding how brain circuits work.'

Dr. B:'Okay, good. So let's say you're working on the neural circuitry in a specific region of the brain, say the visual cortex or the auditory cortex or the motor cortex, or whatever it is you're working on. How would you describe this circuitry? How would you say that the visual cortex does things differently from the auditory cortex? How would you describe that difference?'

Dr. M:'Yes. So the visual cortex is very much tied to processing of motion, visual input, the processing of the patterns of light that come in, so it has to be very good at processing light information. It has to be fast, it has to be resilient to noise, because you get light fluctuations, you get changing light, the fluctuations in light that are inevitable when you're living in the world. So it has to be robust to that.'
Dr. M:'When we take the brain and we dissect it, we find it's got many different pieces and they interact with each other.'
Dr. B:'What is the interaction? How does it work?'
Dr. M:'You know, I've been reading a bunch of neuroscience.'
Dr. B:'No I mean, what is the specific interaction?'
Dr. M:'Well, they interact with each others. But we found that the interaction between the different neurons is not necessary for a specific type of behavior that we care about.'
Dr. B:'Where are the interactions that we care about?'
