Dr. M:'Oh my goodness.'
Dr. B:'There are so many things we are going to talk about today, but first, let me just ask what is the purpose of the research that you are doing?'
Dr. B:'I have a question from a young student that is interested in how the brain works.'

Dr. B:'So there's a hierarchy. The higher order cortex is the most important area of the cerebral cortex because the brain has the highest level of connections with the environment. This area is also connected with each other, but in a different way.'
Dr. M:'You know, you see connections with muscles and joints and muscles and connective tissue and skin and all kinds of tissues that we can measure, we can look at.'

Dr. B:'When we move, what are the important principles for maintaining this relationship between the brain and its sensors and its effectors? What is it that allows us to move our skeletal muscles? Are these the important principles that maintain the stability of the brain? Are these important principles that allow for communication? Is it, or, if not, what are the other important principles that allows for communication?'

Dr. M:'So we have our neurons that are electrically coupled to one another, and then we have the synaptic connection, the chemical synaptic connections. We have electrical coupling to one another and we have chemical synapses. So, there are two kinds of synapses. There are electrical synapses and there are chemical synapses. There is also electrically coupled neurons that are not chemically synaptically coupled. There are electrical-coupled neurons that are not synaptically-coupled.'

Dr. B:'And then we have to look at how neurons communicate, how they synchronize one another. But the communication or the synchrony is very important because these are the processes that are essential for the functioning of neural networks, both within the brain and in the body. And they are also the processes that are also essential for the survival of the organism. So, the question is what is it that allows for the preservation of the connections that are important for the functioning of neurons?'
Dr. M:'The higher order cortex, which is the most important brain region, is also connected with other brain regions. So it's connected with the sensory and motor regions.'

Dr. B:'Are there any areas in the cortex that are not connected with anything else? Are there areas that you like, and maybe you would like to work on, and perhaps they're not connected? What are they connected to?'

Dr. M:'Some of them are not. Some of them are not connected. So, we have some that are connected to each other and some are not. There's some that are connected, and there's some that are not connected to any other areas. So, if you're looking to connect with another part of the brain or connect with another part, you know, you may not be interested in a region that doesn't connect to anything. So that's the way I would think about it.'

Dr. B:'A lot of people talk about the "default state of the brain" and the "default network," but, uh, how much are these ideas really grounded? I mean, how much work is being done in this area? And how do we define the default state? How do we define the network? What is the default state? Is it sleep or awake,? Is it quiet? Is it silent? Is it a particular region of the brain? How is it organized?'

Dr. M:'But there's not a hierarchy in the sense that you can take one small neuron or a small group of neurons, and you can examine their response to a specific stimulus and then determine how they interact with the rest of the brain.'

Dr. B:'What kind of neuroscience is this? What kind of research is it? I mean, what is it? What are we looking at? What are the things that we are looking at? What would be the best way to look at it? What do you see? What do you think is the best way to go about it?'

Dr. M:'Well, first of all, we are looking at neurons, and we are looking at neuron dynamics, and we are interested in how neuron behaviour depends on membrane properties, but also on synaptic interactions. So, neurons that express the same voltage-dependent channel proteins, we don't want them to behave the same way, but we want to understand the underlying properties of each neuron, and to understand the way that synaptic interactions work. So, that is part of the basic principle that we are interested in.'

Dr. B:'How do we get from this point to the implementation of the brain?' How do we get from there to where we are currently with the implementation? What is a path forward? In other words, what are the things we are looking at, and the things that we want to understand? What would be best way to go forward?'
Dr. M:'In other words, how does it work?'
Dr. B:'What is the main goal of neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'Well, you know, you've got to figure out the role that the brain plays in thinking, and learning, and working, and understanding the world. So, there are many different kinds of questions that we would like to answer.'

Dr. B:'In other words, how can we break down the work that neuroscience does into its basic principles? Is there a way of breaking it down into its basic principles, and then, we can work with those and do the rest of the work?'

Dr. M:'I think that's a good way of putting it. I mean, you know, we like to think of ourselves as being able to sort of fit pieces of our work into categories, or groups of work, that we can think of as being somewhat related. So, you know, in the early days of neuroscience there was, you know, there was some sort of a debate on whether you know, was it the kind of right way of going about understanding how the nervous system worked?'
Dr. B:'And, uh, I'm going to give you a little bit of that, but I want to sort of ask you about your work and your views in a little bit more detail.'
Dr. M:'Ok.'

Dr. B:'I'm very much on the side of the early days of science when it was, in fact, very very different to the way we live now, but I'm very much in favor of being able to use new information to refine our understanding of how to do our job.'
Dr. B:'Now, what is a neuron?'
Dr. B:'When is a good time to study the brain? What would you suggest?'
Dr. M:'Well, when it is exciting to be involved in studying brain function.'
Dr. B:'What would be the best place to study the brain?'

Dr. B:'What is an example of a fundamental thing in the brain, and what is the role of the brain in that fundamental thing? Let me give you an example that comes from the area of my interests, which is how brain rhythms can be the mechanism for this process.'

Dr. M:'Sure. So, the principle of the pacemaker kernel, which has to do with the maintenance of stable frequency in the brain, has been studied and studied in many, many different types of animals and different species, and in fact, the pacemaker kernel itself is a very simple, small network of cells, and it does not depend on synaptic interactions to produce its stable period.'
Dr. B:'Okay. What happens when you remove synaptic interactions, and therefore what we see is that the time constant remains the same, but the network becomes unstable and oscillatory.'
Dr. B:'Why is there a need to study the brain? What are the primary goals?'

Dr. M:'The primary goal is to understand how the nervous system functions as it is, the brain is just a very tiny portion of the nervous system, but it is very important, because that's the starting place from where it can all arise.'

Dr. B:'Do you agree with the primary goal, to understand how the brain works? If we're already aware of how the brain works, it would be very convenient to understand how to manipulate those principles and use those as a tool to understand how we can control the brain. It would be very convenient.'

Dr. M:'You should probably think of it as a whole field, with different types of experimental methods that can be used. So you're thinking of things like MRI or other kinds of neuroimaging and biophysical measurements of neurons and things like electrical recording and all of the different kinds of measurements that are possible.'

Dr. B:'That's right. I'm going to start with what I don't know. It's the kind of what I would want to answer in a few minutes. I'm going in a few different directions. One way is to say, 'Well, what is the big question? Is it about what the brain does? How does the brain work? What is the big question?' I think that would be a really good starting point.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:'What are the problems and goals of neuroscience today? Do you think that neuroscience has a particular path forward in the next 10, 20, 50 years? Are there particular issues that we should address first? Or are there areas we should avoid because they are not tractable at the moment? Or do you think we should look back and reexamine how we did things in the past?'

Dr. M:'I don't know. I guess you probably think more about where you're going to look rather than what problems there are. So, one thing I'm going to look for is how different systems in the brain work in a biological system, rather than necessarily to try to solve some particular problem. I guess, I know a little bit about the problems of neuroscience.'

Dr. B:'That is indeed a very broad perspective. But in particular, what would you say is neuroscience's fundamental question? And what are the fundamental research questions that are being asked about, say, the next 10 years? What I'm talking about are the questions about what we are trying to find out about the brain. Let me put it more concretely and say that there are at least four questions about the brain that I would like to understand.'

Dr. M:'So I think it's the brain is really what the focus should be on. The brain and its interactions with other parts of the body. Because, as you're saying, we're really thinking about how things work, or how people think about how things work. So, I mean I have the example of our brain.'
Dr. B:'You're trying to list it all so that I can think of it in a bigger context.'

Dr. M:'So, to be honest with you, I think a lot of people who are just thinking about doing neuroscience studies are, they think of it more as a subfield or as a field that is similar to chemistry. And when they get to the biophysical recordings of neurons, they think 'well, I can only use electrophysiological methods.' And it can be. But they often then get excited to think about other kinds of measurements that they wouldn't ordinarily think about doing.'

Dr. B:'It's just like how people are fascinated about the history of the mind and neuroscience, and are excited about doing it. It's a similar kind of curiosity to be honest. But it's, it's, there's a lot to think about. And there's a lot of ways to be able to understand a system. And then the question that's the interesting part of it is, what is the function? What is the brain function? And what is the goal of the brain?'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'But what is the big picture? There are a lot of things that are different. So here are some of them: in chemistry, you can choose which elements are going to make up the composition, but then there are a lot of possibilities that can be done in neuroscience.'

Dr. M:'Well, you can answer that either way, by saying, I study neurons, I study synapses, I study networks. You can study neurons, but you can also study synapses and networks. You can get very different conclusions by doing that. So, the idea is that the brain is more than just cells, neurons, and synapses, and that the brain has to operate in a very rich interplay between those many different components.'

Dr. B:'But how does it work? In particular, when I was in elementary school, I learned that when you send signals into a brain and ask it to respond, it gives you an output. But what if you are not interested in the output? What if you want to understand how the brain handles input? In which case, you would have to look at the response patterns and correlate them to input patterns to see how the brain handles those input patterns.'

Dr. B:'The brain is organized into a hierarchy of interconnected structures in which the components interact with each other. In order to understand how this occurs, it is necessary to understand how the organization of the different layers and layers interacts with each other. This is what I call the neuronal syntax.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'

Dr. B:'I understand this interplay, but I can't explain the why. You understand it, but you don't explain it. So it is the reason why I'm a bit worried, how you can go into the brain with the idea that you have a lot to figure out, and then all you have to figure out is the mechanisms that explain what we see in the brain, or that's not the case.'
Dr. B:'How do you break this down, in the sense of a neuron, for example? Or a synaptic junction? Or a network? And so on?'

Dr. M:'So, a neuron can be a synapse, it can be a network, it can be all of the above. A synapse can be a network. It doesn't have to be. But in general, in general, in all species, a neuron is the most general unit, because a neuron has to be identified before you can study other properties. And that is usually the case, because they have to identify the cells.'

Dr. B:'Let me start with synapses and networks and move to the other parts of the brain. And in the process of learning about the structure of the brain, it may be that you can identify more precisely the parts of the brain that are responsible for the operations that you study.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, that's right. So, you know, it depends. You can study a synapse, for example, that is probably not going to give you insight into the brain. But if you can study a circuit of neurons in the brain, that's going to give you insights into what the brain is doing and how it works. And then you can move to the rest of the brain, and maybe you have a model for the rest of the body.'

Dr. B:'You know, it's interesting, though, in the sense that if you want to be able to understand how the brain works, it's a prerequisite, and I have to say, the understanding of how the brain works. But this is a prerequisite for understanding how the brain works and what it is actually doing. What does it do? What is the brain's job? And what is its output? What is it?'
Dr. M:'I'm asking you because you're saying this is the most important thing, and it's going to help us understand things in the brain.'

Dr. M:'Well, I suppose when I was studying biology, neuroscience was something that I would have to read about in a book somewhere else, but you know, I think in terms of the kind of the underlying science behind what is in our minds, you know, we always knew that you know we didn't know that much about how cells and how the brain worked. We didn't know how neurons worked.'
Dr. B:'So how did you get into neuroscience?'

Dr. M:'Because, you know I actually started in a physics laboratory where we were doing studies of how cells were changing in response to changes in the intracellular ionic currents. And so that's how I started and it changed and then I started reading about neurophysiology and I started reading about how the brain works and about cells, but how the brain worked in detail. You know, the brain is made of cells.'

Dr. B:'I didn't understand the math behind the biophysical models. But that was not a big deal. It was okay. It was interesting and that was the beginning of my research. I was fascinated by how simple things can work with the help of other simple things. It was a real adventure. And the best part of it is that when I started out, there was a shortage of research equipment, a shortage of computers.'

Dr. M:'When I first started graduate school, people were asking about neurons, synaptic transmission and ion channels, but by the time I started graduate school, neuroscience had come to be a subfield of biology, because the idea had been that we should know how many neurons, and how their circuits should interact.'
Dr. B:'Well, how do we know that? How did we get our way into neuroscience, as it's now? We have to look at our own history.'

Dr. M:'Well, let's take a good example, the central pattern generating networks, you know, the pacemaker networks that produce rhythmic activity, and we're always thinking about how those networks might be produced.'
Dr. B:'But those are simply circuits.'

Dr. M:'No. Those are circuits of neurons that have been assembled in evolution, and by evolutionary selection, in order to perform specific behaviors, so they're circuits that are biologically essential, biologically appropriate to their role, and then the role is one that has changed over evolution, as the brain has evolved, but the role has to change, the neurons have to change their activity in response to changes in environment.'

Dr. B:'In this sense, then, how do we get from circuits to behavior, or at least to circuits? How are those connections built? And the way that we're asking that question is by looking at circuit evolution, because that will reveal a lot about how the circuit is built.'
Dr. B:'So what changed the course of your career? And when was that?'

Dr. M:'I was still trying to figure out why neurons fire the way they do, and why the brain works the way it does and the behavior changes. So I started graduate school in 1978, and it was an era in which there were very strong biological, psychophysical and physiological influences on understanding the brain. The best place to do neuroscience then was in Germany.'
Dr. B:'Why Germany?'
Dr. M:'Because of the way the brain is wired. So Germany had the largest experimental neuroscience infrastructure.'
Dr. B:'What was the first book you read?'
Dr. M:'The first book I read was a book about how cells were organized and how they functioned.'
Dr. B:'Did you ever ask about what makes neurobiology the right branch of science?'
Dr. M:'Yes, I think we asked about what makes you want to become a neuroscientist, but I think some of the things we asked might be different from today.'

Dr. B:'It's a funny thing about the way things work, but the two are related. There are not many subfields in science where it's very difficult to see how the subfields can be related to each other, but the two fields are linked together by the main goal of finding and understanding the function of neurons in brain circuits, the main goal of biology. And then, of course, how these functions can be translated into human behavior, which is the goal of psychology and philosophy.'

Dr. B:'The reason is because in those days, the way we approached brain dynamics and function was in a rather naive way. So, that is when I entered the field. And it was my first meeting with Marder, that was in a graduate student meeting. And I was very curious about her. So I decided, "Oh, what are these people doing? It's just going to be a short question? But it was never a short question.'
Dr. M:'And so we started our collaboration. We have been collaborating ever since.'

Dr. B:'I have read the paper in which you describe the mechanism of neuronal syntax. It's very impressive, both in terms of the scope of the questions that you asked, and in terms of the depth of thinking that you're taking.'
Dr. M:'Thank you, it's really interesting.'

Dr. B:'Now we are talking about the future of the field. And so, the question that I'm asking is what does the future of neurosciences look like? And what I'm looking at is what is the most fundamental question that you can ask at the intersection of neurosciences and psychology. Or at the intersection of psychology and neurosciences, in terms of the fundamental questions.'

Dr. M:'Well, I'm thinking, and I'm just talking, because I'm actually a scientist, and I can think about it in a way that you are not.' So I'm going to take you to a little bit of thinking about what you're thinking about. And this is just to talk about the brain in general, and we'll just take it a little bit to the future. But let me first try to answer a question.'

Dr. M:'What was really amazing about it was, it was one of the early attempts to find mechanisms for neuronal differentiation. And so you're trying to find mechanisms of neuronal differentiation, and you're trying to study evolution. And so you can understand evolution, and so on. And this is when, for example, I first started graduate training, when people were asking about genes, and how genes should be expressed, or how neurons should be studied, and how synaptic connections should be studied.'

Dr. B:'And so you're looking for the right questions that can be studied with the right tools, in the right way. So you're not just looking for the right tool to study a neuron, because you might be surprised, that's a tool in the wrong way.'
Dr. M:'Exactly, yeah.'

Dr. B:'Well, it was a very different time. There were no computers or anything like that. So it was a different age. And it was actually exciting. I got to do something that I was interested in very much in a different era. There was a lot to learn, but also, I was able to understand the problems, and make some progress, and try to go forward. I think, with a lot of my peers, it was a bit too exciting.'

Dr. M:'To the extent that the experiments that you are working on are not going to be of direct importance to what you do in the rest of your career, you may not realize it, but the rest of your life will depend on the answer to that question.'

Dr. M:'But, also that you are describing here, you are trying to connect a series of events which I had studied. I had been doing biophysical studies of synaptic transmission. And so I was working with synaptic transmission. But, and I had seen synaptic transmission as a property of the biological neuron, because I was studying electrical synapses.'

Dr. B:'And when I saw that, I had this intuition, or insight. So I was very curious, and Marder was also very curious about what was the mechanism, so we started looking at the possibility that the same kind of mechanism was utilized by electrical synapses, which is the same synapse class of neurotransmitter, so that we could, maybe, maybe find out that electrical synapses were used in a biological synapse, which would allow me to make that connection.'
Dr. M:'So that is how we started?'

Dr. B:'Yeah, so when it got to be clear that we were on the right path, it was very exciting. So, so I got into it, and we went looking for a mechanism, and we found the thing that we have now called the synaptic transmitter. But this is the reason why I'm so optimistic that we are on the right path. There are so many ways of doing things. It's so, there are so many ways to look at it.'
Dr. B:'So it was a big change in the history of neuroscience. Why did it happen?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think it happened because a lot of people decided that because we had gotten our PhDs, and we had done biology, we were gonna stay in biology. And some people became biologists, but they didn't go into neuroscience. And the people who went into neuroscience came from a variety of backgrounds.'
Dr. B:'I'm curious. What did you do to prepare for a career in neuroscience? Did you go to school and study a lot of different things? What did you study?'

Dr. M:'I did. I studied physics for my PhD. I didn't expect to be a scientist, but then when I started graduate school I found I liked biology, and then I found I liked neuroscience. And you know, so the change of being in neuroscience was more like I was in biology.'
Dr. B:'And you worked on it all the way? How many years did that last?'
Dr. B: 'Do you have any ideas about how neuromodulators might affect the formation and function of dendritic spines?'
Dr. M:'No.'
Dr. B:'What about you, Marder, do you have any ideas?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, I think it's probably important to be aware that the neuromodulatory system, as you said, has its own set of rules, and it is a little bit difficult to know the rules, but we're interested in knowing the rules that govern the neural circuitry, and so that is one of the rules that we're learning about.'

Dr. B:'So, it would be really interesting to learn the rules that govern this mechanism, and learn how it affects synaptic plasticity in particular, because what has been shown is that it doesn't affect the synaptic strength and it doesn't affect how the synapse closes or open, but it affects how many spines are formed on the dendrites of pyramidal cells.'
Dr. M:'I think it could be quite interesting.'
Dr. M:'No. I mean, they could do it.'
Dr. B:'Do they have a lot to choose from? It is a vast library. And there are just too many possibilities, right?'
Dr. M:'Yes. So I would think that you could find a way to control it.'

Dr. B:'Okay. Well, you know, I'd be happy to look through the literature, I just haven't had time to do it. So I would start with a book called "Molecular Neuroscience" by David Glass and try to find the chapter that is the one that really interests me.'
Dr. M:'Okay. So you are interested in neurons, right?'
Dr. B:'No. I'm not interested in neurons. And if you don't care about the brain, then that is a good start for you.'
Dr. B:'It would be very interesting to find out.'

Dr. M:'Well, they can be a bit moody because you know, every time you look at a particular type of neuron, you know, you see it's dendritic structure or its soma structure or its axonal structure, it's usually one kind or the other. And they usually, you know, they express themselves as neurons of that particular kind. So I think it's really a matter of kind. It's a matter of kind, you know, that is what's important.'

Dr. B:'And in other words, you don't have many options. You know, if you want to control their activity, you're going to have to select from a limited number of options, which is always the case. In other words, there's only so many ways you can control something, and you have to select from this limited number of options. This limited number of options and, you know, it's very much like having a car.'

Dr. M:'So, we did that, you know, when we looked at the first example of a circuit of a neuron that responded to external influences by producing oscillations and then we identified it as a voltage-dependent oscillator, like an oscillator. And then we found other neurons that were voltage-dependent oscillators. And then we identified it with voltage-dependent conductance. And then we went on to find other neurons that were oscillators and identified them as voltage-dependent oscillaters.'

Dr. B:'But the fact that we identified a single neuron that responded to input by producing oscillations, for example, is very different from the question that we are facing today, which is whether we could create a system or a system in the brain that can create the same physiological effects as the single neuron. We have very limited options to do so.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'Now, there is the second option that is to use a different mechanism, which is that the system of neuronal activity that can produce oscillations that respond to the same inputs and yet can produce the same physiological results, the same physiological results. In other words to take the system of the neuron and its connections and its synaptic path lengths and, and the synaptic strength of synaptic connections, and that kind of stuff, and make a system out of that.'
Dr. M:'No, I have no idea.'
Dr. M:'Oh yes, I do. It would depend on the neuron.'
Dr. B:' What neurons?'

Dr. M:' Well, neurons that have a wide range of modulators in their periphery. So if we're talking about the neurons that are neurons in the cortex, we are talking about neurons that have a wider range of neuromodulators in their periphery because the neurons are in their central core, their cell bodies, and it's a very small diameter with their peripherals and then their dendrites and their neuromodulatory inputs that will come out of the periphery.'

Dr. M:'I'm very curious about that. You know, we see this kind of phenomenon quite commonly in the biological world. This is in the biological world, in which, you know, the spine is really a very sensitive site that can be regulated by neuromodulators, and that is a common phenomenon that we see in the biological world.'
Dr. B:'And then I wondered what effect, how the neuromodulator would affect the formation and the function of the dendritic spine.'

Dr. M:'No, no. I don't have any idea how to answer this. I mean, of course I was thinking about this as we were talking and you asked me and then it got me thinking about dendritic spiking and dendritic spike morphology and how it might change because of neuromodulation and it's just so obvious.'

Dr. B:'Well, that's a pretty obvious answer. I was looking for something that was not so obvious, but the idea that's the sort of dendritic morphological changes and changes in dendritic spining that are brought about by neurotransmitters and neuromodulators is pretty obvious. What about those changes? Could you comment on that?'
Dr. M:'Sure. Let me think about that for a minute.'
Dr. M:'Not in detail.'

Dr. B:'But what would the basic rules be? Is it possible for a specific neuromodulator to target a particular type of dendritic spine in a particular layer and in a specific direction and affect the structure of the spine, but not its function?'
Dr. M:'There are lots of possible mechanisms.'

Dr. B:'So is it possible that a given neuromodulator can affect the formation and functioning of dendritic synapses in specific layers of a specific direction and in a specific manner? Are there are specific neuromodulators that could, for example, be used to increase the probability of synapse formation between two neurons with overlapping domains?'
Dr. M:'Well I mean, the spines have the potential to become a site of complex molecular regulation in themselves and that would depend on the pattern of activity, but maybe, well I don't know.'

Dr. B:'Would you be able to give me some examples? I mean, what are some things that are known, or could be done in the lab that might be affected by neurotransmitters and drugs that would affect spine structure? Do we have any ideas? Can we give examples? Can we say, oh, here are some examples that we can test?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, you know, the, the dendritic spine structure and their role in determining function is the most interesting thing, so maybe that will be the thing we learn from it. So, I mean, I, it sounds like, you know, something like that would be interesting to explore and try to see how those different rules might interact.'

Dr. B:'What would be a simple example, though, that might be studied? Can we give some examples and then talk about whether they're possible? And maybe there are ways of using that simple examples to see whether these things are possible. Do we have any examples of anything we've studied and the impact of the neurotransmitters or drugs on spine structure and function?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, so we had some initial work on this, back about 20 years ago, so we were interested in the formation of the spines, and it was really interesting that as neuromodulators were used they actually affected the frequency and the amplitude of the bursts that were generated by the neuron, so, like dopamine actually increased the burst frequency, and we found that dopamine and serotonin and other modulators all of a sudden had very strong and long-lasting actions in the spine.'
Dr. B:'You don't know. And how might the dendrite be able to be modulated by the activity in a specific pattern, even if it's just simple spiking activity?'

Dr. M:'Oh I think maybe it depends. I don't know that it's possible to just modulate a particular part of the dendritic tree but you could have like the dendrites as part of the modulator circuitry, if you will.'
Dr. B:'Okay, do you have any thoughts about the importance of these mechanisms to the formation of neuronal syntax?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, I'm thinking they are important for dendritic spiking and dendritic inhibition.'
Dr. B:'What are the mechanisms that would be responsible for this, so that I could understand the physiological significance of this insight?'

Dr. M:'I'm going to give you a hypothetical answer. I think there are many mechanisms responsible for this. And there are neurons that are activated that are responsible for this. I think probably it's something like an oscillator that would cause a different kind of voltage to be present across the membrane in different phases. And then I think there are a whole bunch of other factors. I'm sure there are a whole lot of different factors that play a role in this because the structure of these neurons varies.'
Dr. B:'It varies substantially in the pyramidal layer of the CA1 region and CA3 region.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's obvious that dendritic spiking is important for neurons to be able to get messages to the surface, because of synaptic connections, because it determines synaptic strengths. But I mean, it can also influence the strength of other circuits and even the stability of the network itself.'

Dr. M:'Well, certainly neuromodulators can have an effect on the development of spines and on their response to neuromodulators. And we already know from previous work that neuromodulators alter the morphology of spines and also their electrical coupling to the underlying neuron. And in some cases they change the synaptic connections between the neurons and the axons.'
Dr. B:'And in turn would the connections change the synapses themselves, thereby altering the synapses themselves?'
Dr. M:'Right.'
Dr. B:'Is there any way to quantify the changes of dendritic spine morphology?'
Dr. M:'Not really.'
Dr. B:'What are the chances of finding a way to quantify the change of spine morphology?'
Dr. M:'Well, not really. We found some models that suggest that the parameters of a synapse can be altered, either by a change in the synapse itself, or through changes in the synaptic environment.'
Dr. B:'Could we make a study about this?'

Dr. M:'No. I mean, you see, the study of these things, is... we have this general understanding that we think that they're relatively fixed. And it's really important to have that... not a theoretical understanding, but a conceptual understanding, of how these neurons work. We find... it's very important, for instance, to have this understanding of how the different dendritic spines come into being.'

Dr. B:'Is this a fair assumption, then, that if a synapse is changed, it would affect the function of a neuronal network? Would the network become less responsive to inputs that it was previously responsive to?'

Dr. M:'Yes, absolutely. Because if you change a synaptic connection in a cell, if you change the postsynaptic neuron, the synapse is going to be different. I mean, this is a big deal. So it's going to change the circuit function.'
Dr. B:'Well, that is, uh, that's a good argument. I wonder if there are other studies, uh, where this could be more effectively argued?'

Dr. M:'Yes, indeed. There are some examples in the crab, Cancer borealis, where the same set of neurons in the stomatogastric ganglion that makes up the foregut also makes up the stomach and produces gastric mill rhythms that control the chewing and swallowing of food.'

Dr. M:'Well, it is possible that neuromodulators will play a role in the formation of dendritic spine because dendritic spine formation is regulated in part by intracellular Ca 2+, the calcium channel density, and neuromodulators can affect intracellular calcium concentration. So, this is a possible route by which they could potentially influence the formation of dspines.'
Dr. B:'Do you have any idea how to test this idea?'

Dr. M:'What you'd need to do is you'd need to study, for example, the effect of an increase in intracellular calcium in the neuron that generates the spike. Because if there is a spike in the cell and the cell is calcium-dependent, then you would need to increase intracellular calcium to determine the effect of a potential increase in the density of calcium channels in the dendritic spine.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's possible that neuromodulation could alter the strength of synaptic inhibition at the dendrites, which is important to the formation of spines. The other possibility, I guess, is that it might affect the dynamics of the ionic currents and channels that are important to the formation and regulation of these processes.'
Dr. B:'Is there another possibility? The possibility that this is an independent process? In other words, what are the mechanisms? Or what is your best guess?'

Dr. M:'I'd be quite surprised if modulators have that much effect on dendritic spining. We have some data on dendritic spine formation and function under different conditions, and I'm quite convinced that they have no effects on dendritic branching at all, nor on the number of spines per neuron. We did study some of these modulators in different preparations, and I think they have absolutely no effects on dending. They can only alter the properties of the dendrites themselves.'

Dr. B:'What I'm asking for is, what might happen is the formation of dendritic spine at the same frequency and in the same condition, only that the neurons are in different brain states, i.e. awake, and in the resting condition. In other words, a simple way to alter the formation of the dendritic spine, that is the basic mechanism of memory consolidation, is to affect the activity of the same mechanisms that formed that spine in the first place.'

Dr. M:'I do not have any ideas about that. It is possible that neuromodulators will have a big impact in the way that we think about dendritic spiking. Because we believe that dendritic spike detection is important for information processing in neurons, we would certainly be open to the possibility of neuromodulators changing the extent to which dendrites contain spikes.'
Dr. M:' Oh, I mean, like, the structure of neural synapses? Like, the regulation of synapses, or the regulation of dendritic branches?'

Dr. B:' Yes. Like what is the state of the system and its activity? Do we have to go to a very specific state? What would be the effect? What would that do? What would that make the difference?'

Dr. M:' Yeah. I mean, yeah, there are a lot of factors. There's a lot of, as far as I can see, a lot of parameters that you can vary. I mean, the activity of the network has to be regulated. That's probably the first thing, so that's gonna be regulated by activity and by other processes, so it'll be regulated at different levels.'

Dr. B:' Is there any area at all that would be particularly sensitive to the dynamics of a specific neuron or neuron? Like, for instance, a specific area or group of neurons in the network? Dr. M:' I don't know. Well, let's see.'

Dr. B:' Well, let me tell you that we're working at a variety of areas, and in particular, at a few areas, and in many cases, at a single neuron. And in these situations, in some cases, at many neurons. So in some cases, there are single neurons or, or single neurons that respond.'
Dr. M:' Okay.'

Dr. M:' Well, I mean, it could be a large region, but it could be a relatively small region. It could be that the dendritic branches are the most important branches for regulating the system. But the primary branches, and then some of the processes in the main neuron. I mean, but you might be able to find, if you do a lot of research, some neuron and just figure out the best point to measure, because that can be a pretty big question.'

Dr. B:' Yes, that. So, I was asking, you know, if you could, um, if you had some ideas about the effect of, um, dopamine or serotonin, um, you know, other neuromodulators, on the formation and function, the structure of dendritic synapses or other areas, you know, such as spine development. So what I'm wondering is, uh, what's the best way to test, uh, the effects of these substances?'
Dr. M:' Sure. You can do a whole bunch of different experiments, because we know that dopamine strongly inhibits dendritic arborization in crabs.'

Dr. B:' Well, in other animals. But what about in mice, where they have the advantage that they can do a lot of interesting stuff. But, uh, you know, how would you go to, uh, that, uh, in mice? Because it is a, uh, very difficult thing to test in mice.'
Dr. M:' Well, so, there's a couple of problems. So one is, is that we can't block the release of these substances and see how they act, but we can block the release of, you know, the cotransmitters.'

Dr. M:' So, you know, dopamine is released, um, in many, many neurons that are not projection neurons, so that would be the first place to look. I mean, because you could take any of the neurons that release dopamine and look at the effects of dopamine on dendritic spination, or the effects of dopamine as a synaptic transmitter. So the first thing would be to look at any of the neurons known to release dopamine and see what effects that have on dendritic branches.'
Dr. B:' And then, and then I would, I would, I'd go back and I would look at some of the projection neurons and see if any of those effects are relevant for the formation and function.'

Dr. B:' Well, as in, like, how the different parts of the spine are formed? How they connect, or what we know about their function? I mean, so that there is a sort of, like, a roadmap of how to progress, how to move forward with the research... or, or, well, it's not a roadmap, but the idea would be to say, "I'm going to do this. I'm going to do that.'
Dr. M:' Like, it's not necessarily clear how neurons might be different because the different neuronal classes might have been differently regulated.'

Dr. M:'I mean, there are some studies that have shown that serotonin, dopamine, and acetylcholine all increase the size of dendritic branches and that serotonin increases the number of branch points. I mean, you know there's a lot of studies that show that neuromodulators that have been applied to the intact preparation can also have a similar effect as when applied to isolated neurons.'

Dr. B:'Yeah. Okay. And that may include other brain rhythms, right? There are lots of brain rhythms that can affect the growth and function of dicendritic spines. But what can they do? What are the mechanisms that can control them? And where does it come from? And I'm curious what you think are the critical issues.'

Dr. M:'It could be through the modulation of voltage-dependent conductance dynamics that cause the local depolarization, I think, to be enhanced. There are numerous examples in the literature of the kind of electrical coupling that occurs between the dendrites of different neurons (a phenomenon that you might call passive coupling), and there are many studies about how neuromodeulators alter these electrical connections, how they are regulated.'

Dr. B:'So there is something that can change this relationship between voltage and local depolarization? Are there things that can be altered? What could they be altered? Are there certain substances that could change it? Are there certain forms of behavior that could affect it?'
Dr. M:'Yes, I mean, that is a possibility. It could be a possibility.'

Dr. B:'If you have a drug or some other mechanism that can do this, what does it look like? What would be the mechanism? What is the mechanism of this drug? Are there mechanisms of the drug that I can talk about? What is the pathway for this drug to enter the brain? How can the brain respond to this drug? How does the brain respond to drugs and substances that can modulate these electrical connections? Is there some kind of pharmacological pathway that you can discuss for this drug?'

Dr. M:'I mean I think one of the key points to be made about how neurons are organized in neural networks is that most of the neurons in a network have similar properties, and yet the network has to be able to respond to all kinds of changes that will occur.'

Dr. B:'Okay. So how do we make the brain respond to different situations? What is needed to make a network of neurons respond? Are there certain things that can be increased? What can be decreased? How many times should we increase the local excitation before that the network will respond?'
Dr. M:'Right. Right. So I think these questions, and also the answers to them, will come from the study of the intrinsic properties of the neurons that will be affected.'
Dr. B:'And do we have any research on these modulatory effects on the spine structure?'
Dr. M:'We do. And we have a very strong line of work on the role of neuromodulators and how they interact with electrical coupling. You will find the study by [Dr. Y. Zhang](http://www.santropen.'

Dr. B:'Thanks for that. [In reference to the study by Zhang](http://jneurosci.org/content/2010/10/16/619.full), do we know whether it's possible to stimulate neurons with some frequency range and see what happens? Do we know how long-lasting the stimulation will be?'

Dr. M:'No, I haven't thought about it. I don't know whether neuromodulators can do that because I think dendrites grow to a size where the growth is terminated, so I think that once they're grown past a certain size, they don't get any bigger, so I haven't thought of that as a mechanism that they might be able to use.'

Dr. B:'But you're aware of the fact that, so-called-calcium-spindles that occur in the hippocampus are actually the result of neurotransmitters releasing from neurons that innervate dendrites of pyramidal cells, and that these events occur mainly during sleep and wake-up states, and that they can affect the stability of the dendritic spine.'

Dr. M:'Yes, yes, I'm aware that this may be relevant for that, but I don't know that I'm aware of it being a specific mechanism that they might use it to change things, so I haven 't really thought about it.'

Dr. B:'Do you have any thoughts about whether you're too old to do your own research? I'm just trying to convince people that my age is not relevant. I'm only an octogenarian, and I'm still very active in my research. There's nothing wrong with my age and I'm still motivated, as I am every day, and I'm very happy to be doing this.'
Dr. M:'I'm sure you are, and you're certainly at the forefront of the field.'

Dr. B:'There is a recent report that demonstrates that the neurotransmitter serotonin may increase spine size in the visual cortex, and in that case, it actually was not dendrites that responded to serotonin, it was a spine, which is a specialized structure. So, do you have any ideas? For example, do you have ideas for how long-range fibers might form and maintain connections across the brain and affect their structural integrity? Is there any information about how it might work? What would be the mechanism?'
Dr. M:'I know that there are long-range connections in the brain and that we talk about, so it must have some mechanisms for that.'

Dr. B:'I'm just interested how that might be done? Because it would seem to be an interesting mechanism and maybe one that we can investigate, and, again, this would be the brain mechanism for that. Do you have any information about how this could happen? In other words, what are the brain mechanisms that could affect the dynamics of dendritic spine formation? What would the mechanism be? It would be interesting to know what the mechanism would be.'

Dr. M:'Well, I don't know, there are many, many possibilities, but I mean, I think the most important mechanism, if you're trying to answer this question, is trying to answer questions about the molecular basis of what it means to be a neural network, so that I think the most crucial part of your question is to understand how the basic cell types that neurons and neurons belong to work together in the brain.'
Dr. B:'Do you have any thoughts about how the various neurotransmitters might affect the formation, function, and patterning of the different brain rhythms?'

Dr. M:'Well, this is something that we have been interested in very, very extensively. So, the first idea that we came up with is that neuromodulators, for example, could be released by neurons that innervate the spine of a neuron and they could, if they were released into the synapse, could actually inhibit the release of neurotransmitters at the spiny tip of that neuron. In other words, they could be co-transmitters.'
Dr. B:'And how would they do that?'

Dr. M:'So, that's an idea, it's a simple idea and we have done a couple of experiments with this. So, for example, we found that dopamine can co-transmit with acetylcholine, and the co-transmission of these two substances together can have an excitatory effect, and that actually occurs at the synapse between a motor neuron and a neuron that activates motor nerves.'

Dr. M:'We know that they can have significant effects on the dynamics of neuromodulatory projection neurons, and also they can have a dramatic effect on the way in which other neurons behave, by acting on a circuit that's not even in the neuron that's doing the modulatory neuron. So they can really have an influence on network performance.'
Dr. B:'What are these circuits? And can we go there?'

Dr. M:'The circuits are small networks. So they're small sets of neurons that are wired to each other, that are located, you know, right in the cortex, the upper layers of the cortex. So the dendritic spindles, which are found in these neurons, are very small, about 0.2mm in diameter, and they're located there, and they receive neuromodulatory projections from neurons located in the  C.T.G., the  C. T.'
Dr. B:'Where can we look?'
Dr. M:'So the location of the circuit is right there.'

Dr. B:'But do the neurons that project to these neurons have a particular function? Do they have any special roles? Or does their sole function to project to these dendritic spindle neurons, and their sole function is to release the neurotransmitter? Do the neurons that project towards the dendritic spine neurons have any special function?  Do they have any particular roles in the network?'

Dr. M:'They have a role in the modulation of the other neurons. So they can cause other neurons to change their function, to increase or decrease their frequency of their oscillations, so their rhythms, and then they also can alter their network properties, like their synaptic properties. So they can modify the networks they're embedded in. They can modify their synaptic properties by altering the properties of the synaptic connections. So that kind of modulation can be important, because it changes the properties of the networks.'
Dr. B:'And can we go to the neurons that project? Do they have a special function? Do they, you know, have special roles? Or do they have, you know, particular roles in the circuit?'

Dr. B:'So we need to go there. So let's go back to the cortex for a minute and we can talk about these circuits in some details. And then we can go back to the brain and find some connections. And then we'll start looking at how the connectivity and the mechanisms of how these circuits change the properties of the network. So that's what I'm asking. Let's go there, and then we can move back to the brain. What are the circuits and how do they function?'

Dr. M:'So it's actually been thought about this a lot, is, there are these circuits that are intrinsic to the brain. The pyloric circuit, for example, has to produce coordinated activity for the entire brain to function properly. But there are intrinsic circuits that exist in the brain that can't be turned off, they're not even modulatory circuits. They can't be turned on, but they are active, because they're involved in the generation of behavior.'

Dr. B:'Okay, can we talk about some of these? Can we talk about some that you're not so much talking about, or ones that we can't just put on the table, and have a dialogue? So if I can just ask you to list a few or list them, and then we could move forward from there? I'm not even asking for the name of the circuits, or the name of the brain rhythms that the circuit is involved in.'

Dr. M:'Okay, so the first one is the one we talked about before, the one that has to do with the movement of the body. And that's the motor pattern generator (MPG) in the stomatogastric system. There are multiple MPGs in the stomato-gastric system of all vertebrate animals, and they each specialize in the generation of different sets of motor patterns, which are used to move the body.'
Dr. B:'So it's more than just spines, it's also synaptic strength. Do you have any ideas how to find a way to measure synaptic strength in a brain that's alive? Do you have any thoughts about that?'

Dr. M:'That's a very interesting question. It's quite difficult because it's difficult to control a brain that's living and in fact, it would be quite interesting to see if any of the features that we describe in models were present in neurons in the intact animal, because in the intact animal we have this kind of whole circuit in a brain that can perform all these important behaviors.'

Dr. B:'Well, you're a good candidate to be part of the effort to understand what is being done there. Do you have a particular goal? Do you know what you'd like to accomplish? What's your goal? Is it, as we say, the complete circuit, the complete circuit. Is it a particular behavior or just a circuit that can work? What's your...'

Dr. B:'I agree with you that it would be quite amazing to see how this circuit would perform with no inputs from the environment. Or, if you want to put it in a different way, what happens to the brain if it's cut off from its inputs, or it's cut off its outputs. Do you have an example in your mind where such a circuit would perform at its best?'
Dr. B:'Is there a particular circuit that you're particularly interested in?'

Dr. M:'Well, we're interested in a whole host of circuits. So we're interested in the influence of neuromodulators on the networks that underlie the motor control of the heart, and how the neuromodulators affect the development and function of neuromodal neurons. How they change the synaptic potential and their membrane properties, so that we can understand the function of the nervous system.'

Dr. B:'So I have been doing some work that involves understanding how activity in the higher order cortex affects how the basal ganglia and cerebellum control the heart. I was wondering whether it's too far from the focus of what you're working on to be relevant to the issue at hand.'

Dr. M:'No, actually I think we're more than interested in understanding how the nervous system controls the heart and how it controls the brain as well. We are interested in trying to understand how the nervous system works and how the brain works. Because I think one of the things that you see is that the nervous system is one of the most complex systems that we understand.'
Dr. B:'I'm interested in how the brain controls the heart.'

Dr. B:'And it's important to say that, that's not to say that every circuit that's not directly affected by neuromodulators is not affected, of course, but it is a very interesting question whether the influence of neuronomodulators can alter how neurons are integrated into circuits, and how they function together in neural syntax.'
Dr. M:'No, I'm not particularly interested in dendritic spiny neurons, although if you put the right neuropeptides in them, they would be spiny.'

Dr. B:'So I'd like to ask you how your research interests are related to your approach to understanding the brain and how the brain's organized rhythms might affect cognition. The rhythms are the basis of many functions. And you can see many of these functions without looking at the brain, but then, I mean, it would be good to look at the brain.'
Dr. M:'So if you look at a flower you have no idea what kind of flower it is.'

Dr. B:'If we go back to the brain, what is the first thing we have to look at? You can't go back to sleep because in fact the brain never rests because there are always new things to be investigated.'
Dr. M:'Oh, OK, so maybe the most important thing to do is to have a look around and see what's happening.'
Dr. B:'You can have a look around, but I don't want to have a look at spiny dendritic neurons.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, exactly, so maybe just have a look around.'

Dr. B:'I have a hard time because of the background noise and what-not. But at least this is something else we have to look into. So, if you can look into this and say, OK, this is not really a spiking activity that we have here, then there is a different type of activity going on in the brain than we originally thought.'

Dr. M:'Well, one of our colleagues was looking at the effects of serotonin on a different kind of neuron, one that was part of the gastrointestinal system of crabs. We didn't really think it was going to make a big difference, but it did. One of the most dramatic effects of serotonin was that it induced dendritic spiking activity in the neurons that it acted on, but not in neurons that were not directly influenced by serotonin.'
Dr. B:'What are the consequences of these effects?'

Dr. M:'They found that if you looked at the synaptic conductance of the neuron that was involved, this neuron had many, many more synaptic inputs from its presynaptic cells than it would otherwise have because of the presence of this new hyperpolarizing spike. So it had this huge increase in synaptic conductance from all of its presynaptic neurons because it was firing on all of them, it was just firing on neurons.'
Dr. B:'Dendritic spines are the ones that form the basis of synaptic plasticity. Do you have any ideas how serotonin might affect that?'

Dr. M:'So, we thought that was a really interesting effect. We didn't expect it to influence dendritic sping. When serotonin acts on dendritic spinges, it acts on dendrites, but not on spines, but when it acts on neuromodulatory terminals, then it does act on both. So we were curious how it would influence dendritic spikes.'
Dr. B:'What was the connection to this effect?'

Dr. M:'So we figured out that serotonin was released from the soma and that it activated a subset of neurons and that this subset of neurons was sufficient to generate the same spiking activity in all of the neurons in the system, including the ones that weren't serotonin targets. So it made us think that there might be other neurons that could play important roles in a larger circuit.'

Dr. B:'Where in the brain are these neurons? Are they in the cortex or in other areas? What is the connection to serotonin? Do these neurons have direct synaptic innervation or are they innervated by other neurons? Are they inhibitory or excitatory? Is it a feed-forward or feedback type of effect? What is the source? What is the target? What is the pathway? What are the mechanisms? What is the effect? Are there other direct effects of serotonin on this circuit?'

Dr. M:'It is. It is. We've been studying the effects of serotonin, because we knew that serotonin could directly influence synaptic transmission. The biggest effect of serotonin is that it directly activates a subset of neurons, so that it's acting directly on each neuron individually.'
Dr. B:'But the spines, as you are referring to, are formed in a short window of time. What were the requirements for synaptic plasticity?'
Dr. B:'What kind of neurons would be influenced by serotonin? Do we know that?'

Dr. M:'We don't, we don't know that, but we do know that neurons that are connected to serotonin that are known to produce dendritic spikes, that were not producing dendritic spikings in serotonin when they were studied in isolation. So that was one example that we just found, that neurons that do not appear to be directly influenced by serotonin are influenced by serotonin, and can respond to serotonin in the presence of this other neuromodulator.'

Dr. B:'Do you think that the direct influence is likely to have any effect on the hippocampus? What's going on in the hippocampus that could be affected by serotonin? What are the direct effects that are happening? What's going in the hippocampus that is not being directly influenced by serotonin? Can you talk a bit more about that? Is there something about the hippocampus that makes it more special, or different, or perhaps resistant to serotonin's effects?'

Dr. M:'Yes. Well, the hippocampus has some unique features that make it special. The first is that it's not a cell, but it's more of a cell. It's got many processes. It's got the long processes that project from it. It's got processes that project out. It's got projections in many directions, that then project out in all directions.'

Dr. B:'Is it important to understand how these various neurons and processes interact with each other? What is the role of interneurons? Do they have special features, different from other neurons? How do different types of interneuronal networks contribute to the function of hippocampal networks? What are the advantages and disadvantages of the various patterns of inhibitory interactions in the hippocampus? How does the spatial navigation that's so prominent in hippocampal circuits relate to inhibition? Can you talk more about this?'

Dr. M:'Yes, certainly, I would like to ask you about this topic. I have just been reading an article by the Japanese author, Y. Ishikawa, who showed that these dendritic spiny structures have been seen previously in the preparations of other species. This has also been seen in other experiments and is seen in both invertebrates and vertebrates, suggesting that this might be a general feature of these circuits.'

Dr. B:'What would make a network of synapses more effective and capable of forming spines? There are numerous synapses at the surface of a spine, and these synapses form a relatively small bundle. However, there are multiple layers of spines that can be created. Dr. M:'Right, and these synaptic input could be graded as well. So, maybe there could be a number of different synapses that could increase the size and the length of the spine at a certain input?'

Dr. B:'Right, there could be. In fact, there are many, many ways in which synaptic strength could be affected. And one way that this would happen is that certain neurotransmitters would work on these spine-stabilizing mechanisms, thereby allowing the spine to expand.'

Dr. M:'Oh, I would like more details about this, because I have never heard this before, the idea of having multiple spine layers. If this is important, this would also explain why it might be difficult to find synaptic inputs because you would not find them all at the same place.'

Dr. B:'It could be that we are talking about two different things. The first one is how the dendritic spine forms, which is how the spine is connected to the dendrite of the neuron. Dr. M:'OK, yes, because, let me think about this, we have been looking at neuron dynamics, and a long-standing feature that we found is that neuron types, in some cases, may have different intrinsic properties, and the same neuron type may be capable of different functions, different features, according to the synaptic connectivity.'

Dr. B:'It would be easy to look at spines in different species and examine the differences between species. This is already being done in the experiments by my group and others to show that, in many species, there is a difference between the formation of spines in cortical layers 1 and layers 5 and 6. Dr. M:'That's a good idea. I would be curious to know how it's regulated, because it's very interesting that this is the only way neurons can do it. But, if it's regulated, that would tell me, how it's regulated. I'm intrigued about this idea.'

Dr. B:'The idea that multiple spine layers can be formed and maintained without losing cortical functions, is an interesting one, and I would be interested in hearing you talk about it more specifically.'

Dr. M:'I don't know, that sounds like a problem that you would want to solve. But it also sounds like a problem to me. So if you were asking me to solve a problem, then it's one that I would find interesting. The other way around, you know, if it were that you were trying to find out how neurons could be able to have spines and that kind of thing without losing their identity, then I would also find that interesting.'

Dr. B:'That's not all the cortex, there's a large amount of areas that are not so much affected by this process. So the question is how would you, or could you do this? And then, it's a question that you could actually answer because there are no real mechanisms for that.'
Dr. M:'Mm-hmm.'
Dr. B:'If you would like to expand on that, or even provide a little more data, I would be happy to. Do you have data from your own research?'

Dr. M:'I do, yes, and I'm happy to. This was a paper that we did a couple years ago, because we thought that maybe they might be useful for your colleagues to know, because it could suggest how to manipulate this circuit of neurons, by doing experiments that would alter synaptic and intrinsic currents. It is possible that, in this case, the changes that we see are a consequence of changes in the strength of the synapses.'
Dr. B:'Is there any reason to think that the synaptic strength is not a causal factor?'
Dr. B:'Well, maybe that is what it is, but what is the physiological role of these spines? Do they have any special physiological role?'

Dr. M:'Well, that is a great question, that is a very important question. What is the role of these dendritic processes? In many other systems, the primary purpose is to take inputs from other neurons, and that is why they usually have branching points, because this makes it easy for these dendrites to interact with other neurons. In the case of this system, I think we can say the primary purpose is integration.'

Dr. B:'What could possibly be the advantages of this? What are the advantages of this circuit for the brain? How could it benefit the brain? I would like to make some assumptions. Let's go with something like this: that there are two types of synaptic inputs to the cell body of this circuit: long-range connections and the local circuit. Local connections to this neuron are connected with local synapses in a random manner.'
Dr. M:'No, not really, I mean, I was just hoping that you might have a nice, long discussion, that would go through some of these ideas and I'd have something to think about while you're talking...'

Dr. M:'Well, there's a whole range of modulators, and their actions seem to be different on spines of different neurons. I mean, it's quite hard to know how they'll be affected by neuromodulators. And they're just small little things, and the role of a single dendritic spine is relatively small.'
Dr. B:'But if they work in combination, perhaps they might impact their target in a much larger way.'

Dr. M:'I can imagine the case where there would be a different kind of coupling or integration in the spines. There would be one set of processes that is very sensitive to local inputs, that would be coupled by the voltage-gated calcium channels to be activated, and the other would be regulated by the ionotropic receptors to be activated. The coupling would be reciprocal.'

Dr. B:'Well, then, what would happen is that the spines could be more responsive to local activity than local activity could be to spines. In other words, the spines would not be controlled in the same way. What would be changed is the way the spines respond to input signals, but not to local activity. In fact, this is what the dendrites of all principal cells do in the brain.'

Dr. B:'So that would be the kind of coupling that could allow for plasticity. Is it even theoretically possible to do that? In other words, does there exist a single mechanism that would allow to change synaptic strengths in a brain state-dependent manner? If not, what other mechanisms are needed?
