Dr. M:'There's many hundreds, it changes throughout development.'
Dr. B:'There is a minimum of inhibition necessary for the brain to function?'

Dr. M:'You know what I'm thinking about right now are these inhibitory neurons and inhibitory circuits. There was a study on the role of inhibition in the nervous system. When you first read these studies they make it sound like it's so easy to see the role of inhibition because you look at a neuron that's inhibitory and you think, oh this is going to inhibit other cells from firing because it's always being inhibited. And then you find this is not always true.'

Dr. B:'So what is the actual function of inhibition? So what is inhibition? What is inhibition? Dr. M:'I work with many small neurons that are inhibited by larger neurons. So the number of cells inhibited by large cells is not very high in this model.'
Dr. B:'In the cortex, that's exactly the case, but the number of cells whose activity is inhibited by larger cells is not very large, and I have to work harder to avoid inhibition.'

Dr. M:'But what is the function of inhibition? It's like what do they all do? Dr. B:'What is the function? What are all inhibitory neurons doing? The inhibitory cell is going to inhibit its targets.'

Dr. M:'No. Not necessarily. Like you know, neurons in the retina are inhibitory to neurons in the retina because they can't be seen. So, neurons can also be inhibitory to each other. There are different kinds of inhibition.'

Dr. B:'Well, the important thing about inhibitory neurons is that they are connected together so that you can have a network in which inhibition is always operating. In the brain, inhibitory neurons are always connected by inhibition, whether it's an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSPs) or an inhibitory postinhibitory potential (IPSPs). Inhibitory neurons are never isolated. In fact, this is the case in most cortical networks, and this is what is very good for me.'

Dr. M:'Why is that? What is it good for? Because if you just make a network in which only one neuron is active, you're just creating a circuit that's going to make all of its neurons more or less fire with every other cell, and then you're never going to get the network to work properly.'
Dr. B:'So if you just have a single inhibitory cell, then the rest of the neurons are going to have no inhibition, right? And this is the same case as you said for neurons in the retina.'

Dr. M:'So it has to be, when it inhibits its targets, it has to do so in a manner that's compatible with what it's supposed to be doing because otherwise it would be a really weird neuron that you wouldn't want to have in your nervous system. It wouldn't work in any way.'

Dr. B:'No, so what is it actually doing, if you had to say that, I'm going to figure out what inhibition is and I'm going to make it a better neuron in a sense that it will actually change a little bit in its action. So what is it doing? Well, for a good inhibition, it has to have two things. One is that the inhibition should actually change the firing probability of the target neurons in a short amount of time.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, and second is that the inhibitory neuron should have a target that it is really interested in. That is going to be the most difficult thing to do, right? To find these right targets.'

Dr. B:'Yeah, but the interesting thing is that even these target neurons can be inhibitory, so you don't want to have a target that is, you know, completely independent. And this is what we have to learn. This is what it's like to actually get to the heart of the problem. And it's really complicated and it requires you to think about it for a long, long time. So when you get to the end of the time, there is a simple explanation.'

Dr. B:'But there is a function for inhibition. One way of thinking about it is the neurons that are inhibited have been trained in various ways, they've been given other functions in the brain. They're trained to respond to something else. That training has happened as a result of their interactions with other neurons. Dr. M:'So you can't just think about each individual cell and just focus on the individual cell. So that's where I'm focusing my efforts.'

Dr. B:'And there is the other function that inhibition provides. So inhibition allows them to act, without their brain affecting, but in the case of the hippocampus, the most important domain of the hippocampus is the inhibition of the pyramidal cells from other pyramidal cells. Now this is not a simple task.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:'And what's true for some neurons is false for others. So this is not what is inhibition in some neurons is that they inhibit others and they can also excite them. But this is inhibition. This is inhibition that helps the neurons with which they inhibit each other to fire at different times and in different ways. And this is inhibition, right? Inhibition in this case is inhibition of inhibition. In other words, inhibition in this case is a feedback inhibition.'

Dr. M:'Yes. And the other example would be that, you know, I would just like to call them the feedback neurons, the feedback neurons, because we had these cells that were excitatory neurons and we were able to take some of those neurons and actually turn them into inhibitory neurons and that's a big step. And I remember when we were doing that we were like, I was like, oh my god, there's an example here, we can use this for other things.'

Dr. B:'Well, the next question is whether they have a special function? So it would be a very important thing if we know that inhibition in these interneuron types have a special function. Inhibition in interneurons is very important and there's nothing special about it.'
Dr. M:'I know but it also allows the neurons that are the targets of inhibition to be tonically inhibited.'

Dr. M:'Well, so you can see this gets complicated quickly and it gets complicated quickly because what they found, and this is actually very interesting, they found that the role of inhibition varies across neurons. Dr. M:'And in this case, one of these interneurons is called CbAST5. It's a GABAergic interneuron that was actually found in the central pattern generating circuit of the crab. Dr. M:'Right. So it's like there's two sides to this. Like, okay, let's say, when you talk about a neuron being inhibited, let's say an action potential. Right? An action potential is a specific spike.'

Dr. M:' Inhibitory neurons release chemical transmitters that activate one or more of the other neurons in the circuit. The activation of the next neuron is inhibited by the first, and the inhibitory input is released from the second neuron that activates the first.'
Dr. B:'Why are these functions important?'

Dr. M:'Well, this is one of the most fundamental principles of how neurons are connected to each other. So, in a network of neurons, they're each connected in some way to multiple other neurons, but there are some neurons that have a very important role, and they have to be inhibitory and not excitatory.'
Dr. B:'Now, what is the function of the GABAergic inhibitory system? Why is it so special?'
Dr. M:'This is very important because this is not the way that I had been trained. I had been trained to think that each neuron is responsible for a single kind of function.'
Dr. B:'But when you look at the brain, it's so complicated and complex that you can't be surprised that there are functions that a neuron does not have to have.'

Dr. M:'Absolutely, it's because we are evolving biological organisms, and as an organism we need a variety of neurons to be available to the rest of the organism. Now, there are many, many different neuron types. There are neurons that fire fast, there are neurons that fire slow, there are different neurons for every kind of behavior. So we need to make sure that there are enough neurons available to all of the tasks that we need to perform.'
Dr. B:'And there's a lot of competition for a finite number of neurons between different kinds of neurons.'

Dr. M:'  Pyramidal cells are large neurons that span the entire width of the stomatogastric nerve and then project into the nervous system. They are not small neurons like GABAergic interneuron, which are small cells that project into the stomatotopic ganglion where the three ganglia are located.'

Dr. M:'These neurons are important because they have many different functions in the brain. These neurons are the ones that activate many different muscles in the body.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory circuits are important because they control excitatory activity by controlling the timing of neurons within the cycle and therefore timing of spiking. Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are important.'
Dr. B:'And why are they important?'
Dr. M:'Because they cause a lot of different kinds of activity to occur.'
Dr. B:'Are inhibitory neurons ever affected by any neurological disease?'
Dr. M:'Some of them, maybe not all of them, but a lot of the ones that are affected, are affected by neurodegenerative disease.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for the brain?'
Dr. M:'The brain has many functions.'

Dr. B:'In the last century, we've done a remarkable thing with the understanding of the functions of the nervous system, but now it's time to do the same for the brain. We need a new generation of scientists with the ambition to understand the brain.'
Dr. M:'That's my ambition.'
Dr. B:'Well, good, because this is the field where I'm interested.'
Dr. M:'I'm interested. Oh, in this, and in neural syntax, neural syntax.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are a ubiquitous element in neural circuits and are present in every network neuron we study. In general, these neurons can provide a number of distinct functions: they can change their strength in response to neuromodulatory inputs; they can provide a transient suppression of activity; they can trigger oscillations; they can increase the period of an oscillation; they can increase or decrease the amplitude of an oscillation, and they can act to turn an oscillator off.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of inhibition in the brain?'

Dr. M:'The role of inhibition in general, in general, is to make a network behave as you want it to behave, by altering the strength and time course of synaptic connections within the network. So it is useful to a network that is behaving correctly. But if it's malfunctioning, it can be harmful, because these neurons, as you mentioned, can alter synaptic connections.'
Dr. B:'Who are these inhibitory cells that can exert these changes? How would we characterize them?'

Dr. M:'One of our fundamental questions is how the brain uses sensory and motor inputs to produce behavior and then to create new perceptions. What I'm finding, that the brain is more complex than I've ever expected, is that there are multiple circuit mechanisms that are co-evolving in the brain to produce behavior, and they interact with each other in very important ways.'
Dr. B:'When one looks at the entire system, how do you see the circuit mechanisms that will be needed to accomplish the functions that you've outlined above?'

Dr. M:'There are multiple circuit mechanisms of many types that are working together at the same time in every neural circuit, and that all of these circuits have to be balanced to perform optimally. There's a lot of work that is focused on the balance between excitability and suppression, and it's critical, because if you are to have the neurons in the network that need to work together to produce the behavior that you want, they must be tightly regulated.'

Dr. B:'In the brain, how much excitation should go on at any given time, how many neurons should be firing in a given time window, and how much inhibition should be applied? The goal, in short, is to have the proper amount of excitation and inhibition, and this balance should be maintained through multiple means such as a feed-forward and a feedback mechanism, as shown in the hippocampus.'

Dr. M:'I think you might say, that the answer is, 'Yes, because we have multiple mechanisms to balance excitation and inhibition'. The answer is yes. One of the reasons why it is so hard to understand neural circuits is because it is hard to know how neurons and circuit mechanisms in the brain will interact, and you can't measure everything. You can't monitor the brain. You can't see how the circuits in the brain will respond to stimuli, because you can't go to the brain.'

Dr. M:'The brain is a complicated network, with many neurons, neurons are electrically coupled, neurons have different electrical properties, and neurons in a network can have many, many different connections. The network is also regulated by modulators that influence synaptic and intrinsic membrane properties. Inhibition is often a critical regulator of neural function, because it provides a feedback element that allows a network neuron to influence a network's behavior.'

Dr. B:'How would you define inhibition? What's the difference between inhibitory and excitatory neurons? What is the fundamental difference between excitation and inhibition? Why are some neurons excited and others inhibited?'

Dr. M:'Excitatory neurons are ones that increase the frequency and/or amplitude of the network's activity. Inhibitory neurons are ones that decrease the frequency and/ or amplitude of the network activity. Excitatory neurons often increase the amplitude of oscillations, whereas inhibitory neurons tend to decrease the amplitude of oscillatory activity.'
Dr. M:'The answer is, they control the behavior of neurons and of circuits.'
Dr. B:'So why is there only one inhibitory cell type?'

Dr. M:'Because when you look at what inhibitory neurons are actually controlling, you find that each of the nervous system has many different circuits in it, so you need many different types of inhibitory neurons, and it is a relatively simple system to engineer.'

Dr. B:'Is it possible to have more than one inhibitory cell? Are you aware of any, or do you think we are close? Are we close? Do you think we can make it so that more than one type of inhibitory cell can do the same function? If so, how?'
Dr. M:'I think that it is possible to make it so that there can be multiple cells that play the role of inhibiting a particular neuron.'
Dr. B:'Let's begin with the neuron types themselves. What are their properties?'
Dr. M:'Well, they all have a membrane potential, an intrinsic excitability, and an excitability that depends on neuromodulation.'
Dr. M:'Well, they are inhibitory neurons. They control the amplitude of an oscillator.'
Dr. B:'How is that possible?'

Dr. M:'Because they inhibit the pacemaker from generating the oscillator's activity and they slow down the oscillator's frequency. So, it is not necessarily the case that they have a specific function.'
Dr. B:'Can you explain it in simpler terms?'

Dr. M:'Sure, you have a pacemaker that generates action potentials, and the pacemaker is usually electrically coupled to an oscillator. And it generates a rhythmic action potential sequence which is a kind of pacemaker activity. So, there is a pacemaker neuron, and an oscillator. So, what the neurons do is inhibit the pacemaker to slow down its frequency to maintain some appropriate frequency with which the pacemaker can generate a rhythmic pattern of action potentials.'
Dr. B:'So that's very cool.'
Dr. M:'But the neurons that inhibit the pacemaker have an inhibitory synaptic potential, and they are slow, they release inhibitory substances.'

Dr. B:'Okay, I know what the mechanisms are, but I am looking at the output of the neurons in a network. It seems to me that it is the output of the pacemaker neurons that is driving the activity of the neurons in the network.'
Dr. B:'So, you can think about inhibitory neurons as they are 'good enough' for the pacemaker?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, good enough.'

Dr. B:'That is an extraordinary feat. Do you know, who were the people who first identified that inhibitory neuron function and how did you become interested in that? And when were you aware that you wanted to be a neuroscientist?'

Dr. M:'Well the function of an inhibitory neuron is to reduce the amplitude of a postsynaptic response to a strong presynaptic stimulus. Dr. B:' And they are distinct, right? I mean, like, the two are independent.'

Dr. M:'And that's one of the central concepts in neuroscience that I'm trying to explain to people, is that the mechanisms of excitation and inhibition are both important, but are different, and that the mechanisms that we talk about in the nervous system in terms of synaptic transmission are not necessarily the mechanisms that determine how much inhibition occurs. Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons, or the synaptic inhibition from other neurons, is critical for maintaining the robustness of networks. In networks with inhibitory neurons, networks can become stable despite underlying biological differences. Dr. B:'So what is the function of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'I think it is important for keeping networks robust. But we are thinking in a biological sense. This is, I think, a critical problem. Dr. M:'Well, they are like, you know, I'm talking to somebody about a computer, and they say to me, "oh, well, I want to learn programming", and I said, "ok, you got to learn to read," you know, if you want to learn to program.
