Dr. B:'I'm interested in the wiring system, how does a neuron connect to the next neuron?'

Dr. M:'And then the next neuron connects to the next neuron and then the next neuron and this kind of goes on all the way down the nervous system, I mean if you look at a neuron and you look at the different kinds of synapses that are going on it's not just one neuron but many different neurons are being influenced and we know that neurons that connect in the same network can interact with each other and that neurons that connect to different networks can interact with each another.'
Dr. B:'How many neurons are there in the brain, do we know?'
Dr. B:'What is the function for the inhibition?'

Dr. M:'So we do not know the function of inhibition. We know that it can be the maintenance of synchrony, it can be the modulation of excitability, it can be a synaptic inhibition and it can be intrinsic inhibition.'
Dr. B:'The function of the inhibition should be known?'

Dr. M:'There are a lot of ways that these neurons may contribute to an overall function, and many of the experiments that we do depend on inhibitory synapses to some extent, and therefore it is a hard problem to solve.'
Dr. B:'Is there a big gap between the computational problems that inhibitory neurons have to address, and the understanding of how they actually do that? What is that gap?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, that gap is enormous.'
Dr. B:'I would like to hear about it in your view.'

Dr. M:'Sure, well there's a lot to say on it. We're still learning how the brain works. We're still very much learning how different types of neurons work and how their connections and how different neuronal networks function, and so, it's not something we've cracked, but we're working on it, and it's part of neuroscience as we're working on developing new tools, experimental tools, and tools to study the brain.'

Dr. B:'And what are the most important problems to be addressed? Is there some list of things that would most need to be addressed? What would the ideal situation be? What is that ideal? What do you think?'

Dr. B:'But there are many things to learn, and many people to talk about that gap and work towards a solution. What should be the top priorities, and what should be the top priority, and what can we accomplish in a few years? What are the top priorities? Can you tell us about those priorities? In other words, what do you need to learn? What do you need to understand? In other words what are the top priorities for neuroscientists?'
Dr. M:'Oh, the top priority is understanding how neurons and circuits do the things that they do, how they interact to produce behavior, how they interact with each other to produce behavior.'
Dr. B:'Okay. That is what we are talking about here, right? In other words the top priority is to understand how cells do the things that cells do. What do they do? What does that mean?'

Dr. M:'Well, it means understanding all the aspects of cell physiology, because the different neurons and their circuits are regulated by different sets of parameters, and you have to know how they are regulated, because it turns out that they are regulated by different combinations of modulators. So one of the things that has come up is there's been more focus on this side of things than the other side of things, which is the side of the biology where we are doing experiments to find new ways to monitor cellular physiology.'

Dr. B:'Now, the thing to be understood is how the things in the brain are organized, and how they interact with one another. This is a very complicated topic, and one that requires a combination of computational methods and experimental techniques to really understand. Can you give an example of an interesting thing to be explained or explained? Let's say, if I want to understand how neurons and circuits interact, then the first thing that I have to learn is how neurons and circuits are organized.'

Dr. M:'OK, neurons and circuits are distributed across the animal. It is the task of the biologists who study animals to find out how distributed they are, and that's the first thing that they have to do is find out how they're distributed, find out the number of neurons or circuit elements that they have. Find out how their circuits are organized. Find out how they're structured, and what their properties are. Do you want to know how their circuits are structured?'

Dr. B:'Yes, that's what we call the connectivity. It's a set of relations that binds one to the next. A set of relations that connects one to the next is the thing to be explained. Now, the first thing to be understood in neurobiology is how neurons and circuit elements are organized, and what their physical properties are. And this is a complicated topic.'
Dr. M:'And how does that change over time as the animal grows, as they are active, as they are developing, as they're growing, as they're getting older, as they age?'

Dr. M:'I think there are a lot of gaps and we're only beginning to address that. We really only started trying to understand the computational problems that these neurons have to address when we started thinking about these problems in the context of a more general problem of understanding the role of inhibition in the nervous system and the brain. So this is only relatively recently that we started to think about what might be the function of the inhibition.'

Dr. B:'So the inhibition is a general problem, which is the problem of how to control the output neurons, or inhibitory neurons. And as a general problem, it is actually much easier to think about that than the specific computational problems that these specific neurons have to face. We may not have to consider every single neuron, but for a neuron, it may seem to be more practical to figure out how to activate it in a particular way rather than in another way, depending on the goal of the network.'

Dr. M:'I believe the function of inhibitoric neurons is to inhibit other neurons that are in the circuit, and so to maintain the proper rhythmic oscillations that underlie perception, cognition, behavior and all sorts of complex neural functions.'

Dr. B:'Why do we have so many different subtypes of inhibitory neurons, and how do they work together? Can we know their mechanisms? What is the function of the different subtypes of neurons? Is it important to understand their mechanisms, or are they just interesting for their properties? I also don't understand how to answer that question.'

Dr. M:'It is important to understand their mechanism because each neuron has a different complement of ion channels and neurotransmitters. And each neuron is tuned to a particular circuit. And so if you want to understand how neurons work, you want to understand the underlying mechanisms that control their different properties, then you have to understand how different neurons in the brain control different neural circuits. So each neuron has a particular role to play.'
Dr. B:'In other words, each neuron's a bit of a special puzzle, but we don't have a full understanding of how they work.'
Dr. M:'We have a full understanding, but we're learning to understand them, and it takes a bit of patience and a bit of luck.'

Dr. M:'I see that you're asking the wrong question, but I'll answer you anyway.  The function of inhibitory synapses is a common misconception in neuroscience. In general, inhibition is a very different animal than inhibition in other circuits. We call this 'intrinsic inhibition'.  Intrinsic inhibition is a kind of activity-dependent feedback process that is triggered by a stimulus that is not synaptic and that is intrinsic to a neuron.'
Dr. B:'So, the action potentials in the inhibitory neurons are triggered by some intrinsic mechanism in the neuron itself.'

Dr. M:'So that means the feedback loop, in terms of the circuit, is built into the neuron. So, this is intrinsic regulation.  This is feedback to the nucleus that's independent of synaptic or intrinsic synaptic regulation. This is intrinsic regulation by the network. And these intrinsic feedback rules, which are called intrinsic conductance rules, which are part of these intrinsic properties of the neuron, are controlled by the transcription factors that govern neural circuit dynamics.'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are part of the network, and in particular part of the circuits that make up the oscillatory networks of the heart and the stomach.'
Dr. B:'Oh, I see, now we have the function.'
Dr. M:'Yes. I mean these oscillators. We use these oscillators because these oscillators allow us to interact with our food and water.'
Dr. B:'How does inhibition allow for this? So, uh, you can explain that, can you?'
Dr. B:'And what about the hippocampus and amygdala? Are these inhibitory structures?'
Dr. M:'The hippocampus is not a network, and the amygdala is not a network.'
Dr. B:'But when it comes to circuits, are there inhibitory neurons in there that are functionally relevant for the hippocampus and amygdala?'
Dr. M:'They regulate synaptic transmission and they are used as integrators of network activity into cellular and circuit functions.'
Dr. B:'Who are the neurons in the brain that provide input to inhibitory cells?'

Dr. M:'Well, there are two types of neurons in the brain—projection neurons and somatodendritic neurons. There are projection neurons, which send axons through the body and they are responsible for the transmission of information between neurons and the central pattern generating circuitry of the brain. Those neurons that send axons down the entire body—throughout the whole neuromuscular system—are the somatodendrial neurons.'
Dr. M:'In mammals, this is mostly done by inhibitory projection neurons that are used to regulate synaptic transmission, but also by several other kinds of neurons.'

Dr. M:'Well, first, in terms of the central pattern generating networks, the main function of the inhibition is to generate the inhibitory components of the central pattern, so they can get out of the bursting cell group and release neurotransmitter to other cells. So, the important thing to think about is the importance of inhibition to allow a small neural circuit to work, and so that the inhibitory component of the central pattern generation becomes an important aspect of the central pattern generator.'
Dr. B:'And the importance of inhibition is that it allows a neural circuit to work. What is the importance of the inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, the importance of the inhibitory component is that it is the inhibition, or the inhibition, or a function of inhibition, that allows a circuit to work, to work. The function of inhibition is to allow a circuit to work.'
Dr. B:'So, what is the function of excitatory neurons? Are they also central pattern generators or pattern generators?'

Dr. M:'They are not central pattern generators. They are not pattern generators. So, they have functions that are similar to the functions of central pattern generators, because their excitatory components have the function to bring in current, to drive an action potential. So, they are, they can drive action potentials, but they don't have the central pattern generating function.'

Dr. B:'Are they excitatory pattern generators, or pattern generators, because they also release neurotransmitter to their target neurons? Are they similar to interneurons? Do they have similar effects? Are they similar? Do they have identical effects, similar to, uh, the central pattern generators, interneurons, because of the inhibitory effects they exert? Are they similar because of the inhibitative effects they exert?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons, it is not clear that they perform a very specific function. They do release substances, but I think they probably just increase the release of those substances by the neuron that is receiving the inhibitory signal. I do believe they are important because they control the release of substances by the neurons that they are inhibiting, so they make them release more substances. But it is not clear if they are essential for the function that their circuit is performing.'
Dr. B:'How about excitatory cells? What is their function?'

Dr. M:'I guess it is similar, but I think excitatory cells are very important because they have to provide the excitation to stimulate some cell, and some of the cells that they excite do respond to excitation, so it is important that excitatory cells respond to their excitation.'

Dr. B:'What is the function that their neurons perform? There is not a very good definition of what their circuit does. It's not clear what they are for. I don't have a good answer, but it seems to me it is a very important question. I have no idea.'

Dr. M:'You know, I have a very similar comment, although in a different domain. It is not clear what these neurons do because you don't know if they're there to regulate the release of transmitters or if they just increase the release or the level of release of the transmitters that they're regulating. It is not very clear.'

Dr. M:'Well, if you go back to the earliest studies, it seems to me that they were trying to find neurons with activity that matched what they saw in the intact animal. So, in the case of the STG, for example, the pyloric circuit, we were able to study the pyloric network, the network, or the network that produces pyloric rhythms, and we studied the stomatogastric ganglion, which produces the pyloric rhythms.'

Dr. B:'If we find a network that produces a particular rhythmic output in a particular form, we find that network and study it, right? So we can say that there is a network that produces oscillation or a network that produces the pylotic rhythm or whatever it is, but the point is to say what kind of function the network does.'

Dr. B:'So, I don't understand how the inhibitory neurons in the STG control the output of that network. I don't know how they are integrated or if they are integrated by some neurons in the network. If you go back to studies from the beginning of the 20th century, it seems to be that they were trying mainly to find neurons that had rhythmic activity that matched what those were trying to match, but that's not a very good answer. I don't understand.'
Dr. M:'So, it might be the only answer that we have is to say, it was to try to find neurons with similar activity.'

Dr. B:'It's not clear how the inhibitory neuron in the STG will integrate with these other inhibitory neurons that surround the STG. It's not how they are integrated into a circuit. And, we didn't really know how much they are integrated into the network. We know that they are there, but we don't know how important they are. So, that's a very important point.'

Dr. M:'Well, you see, you have to know the function of the circuit that you are trying to understand. Because it's easy to see a single neuron and say it's either going to be up or down, but not how is this neuron going to respond to perturbations? And we really don't know, until we understand that circuit how this cell will behave.'

Dr. B:'How it is going to respond? If I am going to use this as a metaphor, this is the neuron that is sending an inhibitory message to the neuron that is going to send a spike. We don't know what its circuit will do in response to a perturbation. What we have to know is how the circuit will behave. If you look at the function of inhibitons in the hippocampus, and they work with inhibition and excitation, this is what they do.'
Dr. B:'What is the function that excitatory neurons have?'
Dr. M:'They are there because of synaptic connectivity, because neurons can be inhibited by the other neurons in their circuit.'
Dr. B:'And if you take the whole network, the inhibition provides stability so that the network can be modified by inputs, and this is how networks are built in biology.'
Dr. M:'Exactly.'
Dr. M:'We can modify networks to meet our needs, if we modify the inputs that our network is receiving.'
Dr. B:'In other words, the function of the inhibitory system is to serve the function of the principal cells that are embedded in it.'

Dr. M:'There are many inhibitory neurons that are important for the nervous system to function. I'm just interested in the intrinsic properties of neurons that might have nothing to do with network connectivity. I'm interested in understanding how they work and how they control the rest of the system.'
Dr. M:'Well, inhibitory neurons are those neurons that control other neurons, other cells.'
Dr. B:'Where is the inhibition coming from? How are they controlled?'
Dr. M:'They can be controlled by a single cell, or by multiple cells.'
Dr. B:'Are the inhibition signals from the same cell, or are they independent of each other?'
Dr. M:'Well, this question has been on my mind for years because we have identified many inhibitory neurons and we still do not know the function of these neurons.'

Dr. B:'The best guess I have is that these neurons are responsible for controlling the excitability of principal cells. Therefore, the inhibition serves to maintain the stability of the principal cells and to control the dynamic range of the principal cells within the network. This is what I have been doing with my network model: controlling the firing rates of the principal cells by applying current steps to these inhibitory neurons.'
Dr. M:'That is a good hypothesis. That is the best hypothesis that I can offer right now.'

Dr. B:'I agree. Let me ask a more difficult question, then. Is the function of the excitatory neurons the same or different? I mean, in principle, the same, right? And this is where we have the second part of the answer that I will share with you. If you want to ask a difficult question to someone, you should ask it to yourself.'
Dr. M:'Absolutely, yes, I do.'

Dr. B:'What is the function of these excitatory cells? You have mentioned many inhibitory cells that would be perfect for this job. Is it to add some more inhibition to the network? Or is it to fire the same amount of spikes, just faster? Or is it something completely different? Do we know? Does the brain know? Or does it need to be determined? In other words, is it the primary function of these neurons to contribute spikes to the network, or to inhibit?'

Dr. M:'I think the primary function is to contribute spikes to network activity. We know that these neurons fire spikes, and we know that these neurons can fire spikes and they fire many times per cycle. We also know that these neurons are sensitive to temperature changes. So, you know, I would be very surprised if these neurons have not become temperature sensors.'
Dr. B:'It is a plausible theory.'

Dr. M:'It is a very plausible theory, although I would have to run simulations and see what happens when the voltage is stepped. To show you how it works, I think we need to see the effects of changing the membrane conductances. When we go to an animal, when we are studying an animal or when we study humans, we don't measure the activity of every single neuron or neuron that we measure. We measure the activity of a few neurons or many neurons.'

Dr. M:'Let me talk about the other side of the equation. We also know that a major function of a neuron is to release neuromodulatory substances. There are many examples where neuromodulatory processes have been identified and it is obvious that this is an additional function. For example, in the central pattern generating circuits, the pyloric pacemaker neurons, we have identified several neuromodulators that enhance and facilitate the generation of central pattern generators.'

Dr. B:'We also know that these neurotransmitters are capable of affecting other neurons and that their effect depends on time. So, in the central system, the inhibition of the pacemaker neurons is a necessary condition and the release of a neuromodulatory substance is an optional event.'
Dr. B:'Well, let me ask a more specific question. How many neurons are there in the cortex? And please, no, don't say, 'I'm going to estimate.' That's a terrible estimation.'

Dr. M:'Okay, how many neurons are there? The number of neurons has increased since we started counting neurons. We know there are a variety of neurons that are identified as inhibitory. We know there's some that play roles in regulation.'
Dr. B:'And we know that there are other neurons that have specific functions, which are related to memory and processing sensory inputs. And what is the function of the inhibitory neurons?'
Dr. M:'No, we know there are many neurons that fire in the cortex, and their number is still unknown.'
Dr. B:'So, let's just start with the number of neurons in the cortex.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, I would like to be able to say how many neurons there are in the cortex, but, that's not possible because we are still working on the function of some of these neurons. We've identified many neurons that we believe fire in the cortex. We still don't know how many neurons there really are, but many, many neurons fire in the cortex.'

Dr. B:'Right. So here's what I want to ask. How many cells are there? If you can say how many cells there are, I'll say how many cells. Let's say there are 20,000 neurons. What is the function of these cells? What is the function? If you can answer that question, then you will know the function of the neurons, because you've answered the question, and the function of a group of neurons is the function of that group.'
Dr. M:'Right. Right. So let me tell you what we've done, and it's not what you might be expecting. We've identified neurons that fire on the cortex of crabs.'

Dr. B:'Well, that's interesting because we have shown that a small circuit can be made to fire with 20,000 neurons in the cortex of a crab. So the first thing we did is we identified a neuron that fires in the cortex, we call it C1a neuron. Then we identified a neuron in the frontal cortex, and we called it C2b neuron. Then we created a small circuit that connected them, and it fired. It fired because it was designed to do so.'
Dr. M:'Okay.'

Dr. B:'What we have not done is identified the function of the two neurons in this small circuit. So the first step is to find the function of the neuron C1a and neuron C2b. But to find the function, it's not easy. Because it requires looking at the entire circuit, from the very beginning where there are the two neurons, where they synapse. Where they have excitatory and inhibitory synaptic inputs from, where the neurons are connected to each other in the circuit.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. B:'Okay, so let's move forward with what we do know about these neurons.'

Dr. M:'To inhibit the voltage of other neurons that are electrically coupled to them. It's like in the cardiac system; the cardiac ganglion neurons are all electrically coupled, and one of the ganglia neurons inhibits all of the other cells, which are electrically coupled. So, for all the oscillators in the cardiac ganglions to behave appropriately, the inhibition needs to be delivered. It also enables the oscillator to control other oscillators that are electrically connected.'
Dr. B:'What are some of the consequences of the inhibition?'

Dr. M:'The most important one is that the inhibition can be quite long-lived. In the cardiac system, for example, the cardiac ganglionic neurons can fire for hundreds of milliseconds, so they need to be inhibited as long as the system is active, and they are firing.'

Dr. M:'This is a good question because there are some neurons that play an inhibitory role in a neural circuit, but they don't have any particular intrinsic electrophysiological property, such as being depolarized, but the function of these neurons is to inhibit other neurons in the circuit because they are in a different neuron group.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of the various inhibitory neurons in controlling the excitability and oscillation properties of principal cells?'

Dr. M:'The key to understanding how networks of neurons can produce behavior is to understand how neurons with similar characteristics can behave in a different way, and in particular the difference between inhibitory neurons and inhibitory neurons. To get a sense of the role of the different neuron types, we have now a number of neurons with very similar phenotypes that we study in our laboratory and others, but have very different underlying electrophysiological properties.'
Dr. B:'How many different neuron types can be identified in the mammalian brain? In other words, how many cell types do we have?'

Dr. M:'In the general brain, there are three or four neuron types that are likely to be present, including the pacemaker cells that we study, but there are likely to be many different cell types that are present in a brain region, and this could be more or less than four. So this is a very active area of study. One thing that is going on right now is that we have begun to study the cell-type variability in both invertebrates and mammals.'

Dr. B:'Do we know for sure what makes up a neuronal circuit? And do we have a list of neuron types that we can study? If so, what are some of those neurons? What are the key neuron types that are present? What is the main function of these neurons? What is the difference between excitatory and inhibitory neurons? What is their primary wiring? What is the role of these various neurotransmitters and neurotransmitters in the various cell types?'

Dr. M:'You're asking, 'What are the roles of the different neuron populations?' And so this is a central theme that we have been studying over the past decade. When you look back in the early '90s, we were interested in how the brain would be reconfigured in response to neuromodulators and substances, and this was a very active area for us.'

Dr. B:'Now, what do we know about how brain circuits are formed, and what are their primary functions? What would you say are the most important cell types? What are the important wiring? What is their role? What is the contribution of these various neurotransmittters and neurotransmitter systems in the various neuron types?'
Dr. M:'I'm a little hesitant to jump too far back.'

Dr. B:'Then the question is, how many different neuron types have been identified? And the answer is that we don't know. But we can be more specific. We have been trying to answer these questions for the past several years. I'm just asking you what are the neuron types? What is the key neuron types? What are the main functions? What are the roles of these various neurotrans transmitters and neurotransmitter? What are the role of inhibitory neurons?'

Dr. B:'If there is no difference, why do we have so many different inhibitory neuron types? And what is the advantage of having so many inhibitory neurons in the brain? Is it simply so that when some excitatory neurons fire, the inhibition that they produce is much weaker than when there is only one type of inhibitory cell?'
Dr. M:'I don't know yet, but my work on the nervous system shows that they must have a function.'
Dr. B:'How is that? Are inhibitory neurons connected to the nervous system?'

Dr. M:'No, they are not connected to the nervous systems. But we know that the nervous systems are very modulatory and that they can change their responses to neuromodulators, and the inhibitory neurons are the target for these neuromodulators.'

Dr. B:'What are some of the neurochemicals that have some impact on the function of inhibitories? If you know the names of these neurochemicals and their mechanism that they have, would you be able to tell us what that is?'
Dr. B:'What are the most important functions of neuromodulators? Is it about sleep? Is it about learning? Is it about movement? What about brain rhythms? Do they play a major role in brain rhythms?'

Dr. M:'Well, yes, they do play a major role. So I think that the neuromodulators in the brain have been studied enough in the past, and we know that they can produce sleep, so that has been studied. And we know that some neuromodulators can cause changes in learning, and that some can cause changes in movement. And we know in the nervous system that neurons can be activated in different ways and can behave in different ways.'

Dr. B:'And that is why it's important to understand the brain rhythms. That is why it's very important to understand how these neuromodulatory cells interact with these brain rhythms, but that's what you mean by the question that has a particular reference to the brain rhythms, that's why it's important? Is it about memory? Is it about planning? Is it about emotion? What about imagination? What about creativity? What about sleep?'

Dr. M:'So, these are all important aspects of the brain, and I think, so, you know, when you are doing neuroscience you are trying to understand how the brain works in all of these different domains. And I think the fact that some of these are very difficult to study, especially when you have to study brain circuits or you have to study neurons in isolation, right?'

Dr. B:'Is there something that we have to look forward to when we have to use the methods that you just mentioned? Like, is there something that you're really looking forward to? And so on and so on, or are you looking forward to anything in particular that you would like to research? What I mean is, if you just told us a little bit about what you'd like to study, and what you're looking forward to, or, you know, anything, we're all very curious.'
Dr. B:'Let me ask you a question. What is the function of the neuron in the hippocampus?'
Dr. M:'It is a pacemaker neuron.'
Dr. B:'And where are the principal neurons?'
Dr. M:'Principal neurons are in the stomach, so that is a muscle of the stomach.'
Dr. B:'Where are the principal neurons that provide a feed-back loop to the pyramidal cell?'
Dr. M:'They are in the small intestine.'
Dr. M:'the pyloric network must have a function, but the function must be so well hidden that we do not know it'.'
Dr. B:'But why should we be interested in inhibitory neurons? What function can they do? How can they assist in solving the problem of how the brain is organized?'
Dr. M:'So my work shows that inhibitory neurons play a role in creating circuit dynamics that can help to solve that problem.'

Dr. M:'Well, this is a tough question because we don't really know, and there are models that have been built. For example, the pyloric rhythm in the brain is a pacemaker in the pacemaker neurons, and the pacemaker neurons inhibit other pacemaker neurons, thus creating rhythmic pyloric activity in the pyloric network. And the pacemaker neurons also inhibit neurons that control other muscles that are used in chewing or eating food.'
Dr. B:'And what about the activity of interneurons? Are they just a kind of noise that the brain can overcome, or are they critical for the stability of other rhythms?'

Dr. M:'They are important for the stability of all the rhythms, actually, because they create all the feedback circuits, you know, for example, when an invertebrate muscle contracts, it also contracts other muscles around it, and thus the contraction and the feedback can be monitored. And they're also important for generating all kinds of electrical and chemical responses in the nervous system.'

Dr. B:'Well, what are some of the other functions they play in the brain? Do we know the physiological functions that they perform? Or are we only just assuming what they're doing, based on the evidence we have? And we use the term, 'noise,' is that correct? So the term that we use, noise, is that a fair assessment of the evidence we have?'

Dr. M:'No, it's not fair to say that, because these neurons are very important for maintaining all the rhythms. So in that sense, you know, they do have to function. We don't really know what they're doing most of the time, but we know that they're very important for keeping everything intact.'

Dr. B:'Do we know that what we're trying to maintain is critical for brain performance? Do we know what the critical function is? And how does the brain control these functions? Or are we just assuming what the function is without actually looking at the evidence and seeing what happens when we remove the noise? And how does it look? What does it look like? What are the things we have to look at? And how does that affect brain performance?'

Dr. M:'Well, I mean, for example, one of the things we have seen is that many invertebrate circuits, even with neurons that have very different frequencies, they still produce a very consistent behavioral output that is very important for the ability of the animals to navigate through their environments. So even in this case, we know that these neurons are important for maintaining neural circuit stability in behavior.'

Dr. B:'And do we know how they affect behavior? So this is a question that you're also asking about is that this is the question you would like to have answered? And how does this work? What is the role of these neurons and how are they controlled? What is the function of these neurons? And how do we know that these are not just some neurons whose sole function is to keep the brain alive and stable? So how do we know?'
Dr. M:' Inhibition is not just inhibitory, but has a very specific and unique role to play in many neuronal networks.'
Dr. B:' What is it? What is the function?'

Dr. M:' It's a function to inhibit other oscillators. They're not all alike. It's not a global function, like a pacemaker. It's not meant to inhibit every other oscillator, but it's meant to be inhibited by one particular oscillator. It has to be inhibited by the same oscillator.'

Dr. M:' One of the things that you learn in biology is that each neuron type has a very unique set of intrinsic properties, that may be different from other neurons. The same neuron type may have different intrinsic properties in different animals. The same neuron might be different between two different animals of the same type, and the same neuron may have different intrinsic property in different animals.'
Dr. B:' How does this differ from other networks?'
Dr. M:' What is the unique role?'

Dr. B:' So there are two different forms of inhibition, a form that you could call as the 'feedback loop' inhibition and another type called 'feedforward inhibition', which has two distinct roles in neuronal networks. The feedforward type of inhibition is critical for the generation of oscillations. It is a special kind of inhibition that is often referred to as the perisomatic type of inhibition. The function of perisomatic inhibition is to reduce the output spiking activity of the neurons.'
Dr. B:' What is the unique contribution of inhibition?'
Dr. M:' To inhibit, you need to have a set of neurons that are inhibitory neurons and to have a mechanism to inhibit the rest of the network by which you are influenced.'
Dr. B:' In addition to neurons and their activity, what other ingredients do you have in a circuit? Can you name three items that can form a circuit?'
Dr. B:' Inhibition is a fundamental mechanism in all mammalian cortical circuits.'

Dr. M:'Inhibition is a ubiquitous feature of neuronal networks and is an example of evolutionary conservation of an important functional mechanism. It's not the only mechanism for creating inhibition. Inhibition can also be generated by the activation of a hyperpolarization-activated current that depolarizes the membrane from a more hyperpolarized point, a kind of rectification.'
Dr. B:'If this is the case, then what is the function of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'So it's a way of inhibiting voltage excitation from a depolarized to hyperpolarized state. If the excitation is already at a high enough level, the hyperpolarization will just make it increase and increase. So you can see, in general, the main reason for inhibition is to inhibit voltage excitation.'

Dr. B:'Can we put aside the concept of inhibition for a moment, and what we would like to ask is how we can learn anything that we know about the brain if we ignore the effects that inhibition has on excitation?'
Dr. M:'I'm not sure that there's anything to be lost if you put that aside.'

Dr. M:'Well, if you look at neurons that have no hyperpolarization potential, there is no way for them to inhibit themselves because they have no synaptic connection. So, in a network with many neurons, the function of inhibitors is often to provide a feedback mechanism to maintain the structure of networks.'
Dr. B:'Is there a particular example that you can illustrate that you can't get away from the feedback inhibition?'
Dr. M:'It is a fundamental feature of how we understand the organization of brain circuits.'

Dr. B:'What is this fundamental feature and what makes it the fundamental feature? What is the essence of this feature? I mean, I want to be able to define this fundamental feature because it is a fundamental feature, but I want to know what is it's fundamental feature. What makes it so fundamental? So, you have a list of mechanisms that are available. The mechanisms that you're able to use are limited by a number of things.'
Dr. B:'What is an example of inhibition that we have observed in the brain?'

Dr. M:'I'm not really sure that we've observed inhibition in the brain but certainly we have observed many different patterns of network activity that suggest that there are different mechanisms at work.'

Dr. M:'Well, it would be interesting to study this because it would provide insight into how neuromodulators use different mechanisms to achieve their effect on behavior. I mean, I've studied some of this in the context of the activation of voltage-dependent potassium currents. The activation of voltage-gated currents by neuromodulators is one example. In this case, we see a distinct mechanism being used to achieve the same goal, which is the activation of voltage gated currents.'

Dr. B:'In other words, in order to achieve the goal of inhibiting the cell membrane, you have to use a specific mechanism. What are the consequences of the inhibition? In other words, is it possible that inhibition is the key to generating a specific output in terms of a neuron's output?'
Dr. M:'Yes, absolutely. I think it's the key, because it allows for feedback to occur and it allows for neurons to be active.'

Dr. B:'So there are numerous possible consequences for inhibition. I'm going to ask two questions from you. First, are there any potential consequences of inhibition that you find particularly interesting? Second, are there any possible ways in which inhibition may play a role that we haven't covered yet? I'm going to give you the opportunity to address that, and then we'll bring on the audience to respond to the questions.'

Dr. M:'Well, one is that they can provide inhibitory feedback to the central oscillator neurons to maintain the timing of the cycle, for example. So, one of the most exciting things is to watch the effects of manipulating neurons because one always thinks about neurons, they're always just the first neurons that come to mind, but the amazing thing about neurons is the interactions that they have with other neurons, with other circuits and their effects are also really fascinating'.'

Dr. B:'I'm looking for a mechanism, a physiological explanation that might explain this mechanism of inhibition or its effects in the brain, but so far there are really just a couple of interesting examples of neurons that are inhibited by certain chemical substances.'

Dr. M:'Well, you'd ask about synaptic transmission first, but for most invertebrates, it appears that they use a small number of different inhibitory neurons for a variety of different inhibitory purposes. But in some species, the number of distinct inhibitory neurons is very high, as it is in humans, and those inhibitory neurons play very specific roles.'
Dr. B:'What's a good example?'

Dr. M:'I can think of one. We had some colleagues in Brazil who discovered the function of a different neuron to the  C. borealis  nervous system. They found that some neurons that were not thought to be synaptic transmitters, were involved in the control of the pyloric rhythm. They found that they had a number of different chemical substances that were secreted onto the soma of the pylor neurons, and they were very important.'
Dr. B:'Can you tell me the name of this inhibitory neuron?'

Dr. M:'If you're talking about humans, well, we use two different inhibitory neurotransmitters for inhibition of muscles. We use two different neurotransmitters for the inhibition of neurons, such as dopamine and serotonin. We use two neurotransmitters for inhibiting different types of cells in the brain, and so on. So it's not that one neurotransmitter is used for inhibition of different kinds of cells, but a variety of different neurotransmitters are used for inhibition.'

Dr. B:'Well, I mean, there are some examples in the brain where it appears that GABAergic interneurons are used in a very specific manner, but many of those interneurons may function by inhibiting excitation in other areas. In many cases, their ability to inhibit excitation depends on other interneurons. The GABAergic neurons are always on the periphery, and they are the first to be activated in the early response to excitation.'
Dr. M:'Yes, the earliest response to excitation is always GABAergic.'

Dr. B:'I agree, and those interneuronal roles are much more diverse than in some interneurons in other areas, and in many other areas, the function of interneurons is not clear. I would like to get in touch with your previous students who were the first students in the study of interneuronal functions. What is their current status in the field?'

Dr. M:'I guess many of the same, like most students, they're still doing neuroscience, they're still studying brain systems, and they are also taking on new areas of neuroscience, like studying interneuronal relationships.'

Dr. B:'But in this process, what are the challenges that you have faced? What are the areas of science that you are looking for to bring back, and what are the topics that you are looking to study in the next decades? Where are the questions that you will address? What are your aspirations for the next few decades? I'm assuming that you want to return to your original goal of understanding the neuronal syntax, but what is the practicality of this goal?'

Dr. B:'I mean, there is one case where we see that inhibitory interneurons appear to play a critical role. In the hippocampus, the inhibition that they provide is needed for the orderly sequence of firing in pyramidal neurons, which is thought to underlie the sequence of representations in episodic memory.'
Dr. M:'Exactly, it is quite clear that they are the first activated, the first to become active, and the first to play a role in the earliest response to a change of the neuronal inputs.'

Dr. B:'And when they are activated, the result is a specific inhibition of excitation of the neurons that are the first to respond to input, thus giving rise to a unique temporal order of activity. That's how they may function.'

Dr. M:'Well, I've always found it very fascinating to think that inhibitory neurons have multiple functions. Inhibitory neurons are really interesting in terms of circuit design, because we've observed that some neurons can act as either a pacemaker or an inhibitory hub for multiple circuits.'

Dr. M:'Well, inhibition is very important in the nervous system, in my view. It allows different neurons to be segregated and to keep each other off balance, and it allows a variety of rhythmic behaviors to occur, such as gastric mill rhythms, cardiac muscle contractions, or cardiac muscle contraction. And it's important in allowing neurons to release a variety of substances, as you know, that have many functions. And it's a fundamental mechanism that allows different neurons to behave according to their genetic profile.'

Dr. B:'I understand that inhibition allows for a variety of different rhythms in different parts of the brain, but in the hippocampus, I'm not sure how inhibition would be the key to providing rhythm. I mean, it's not clear to me how inhibition allows for rhythms in the hippocampus. The other mechanism that allows for a rhythm is the interneuron, but what are the mechanisms for inhibition? What is the mechanism for inhibition? What are the mechanisms that allow a neuron to inhibit its own targets?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, well, the neuron that inhibits itself is probably the only neuron that is likely to keep its target off. So it seems to me that the role of inhibition is to keep neurons segregated, to ensure that they're not co-transmitters, to ensure that each cell is only firing in the correct rhythm.'

Dr. B:'Could it also be the case that inhibitory interneurons can synchronize neurons with a high temporal precision? So that, in, for example, a hippocampus-dependent memory task, a hippocampal interneuron might be synchronized in the theta frequency band?'

Dr. M:'So the hippocampus is a place where it's really critical to maintain the appropriate rhythmic patterns of activity in the brain. So that's why, you know, the neurons that are there must be kept segregated and they must be, they must be in the appropriate frequencies and they must be the appropriate length of time apart, so that the appropriate patterns of activity can be produced, so it's very critical that that be done correctly.'

Dr. M:'You see, I think it has a lot of mechanisms. I don't think inhibition is necessarily the mechanism. I think inhibition is a fundamental part of neural network dynamics that allows neurons to regulate each other, and to control the rhythmic behavior of many different networks. We use inhibition in many different ways. We use it to release substances, we use it to regulate the voltage of the membrane, we use it as a control mechanism.'

Dr. B:'What are some ways that we use it? In the hippocampus, we know that inhibition is critical for gamma and epsilon rhythms. We know that inhibition is an important part of the hippocampal network. What are the mechanisms and the mechanisms? What are the molecules and the mechanisms that inhibitory neurons use? Do we know? What are they? What are the molecular mechanisms of the inhibition?'

Dr. M:'So that's the point of our study. We're studying the mechanism of regulation of a network, the mechanisms by which the neurons are regulated. We don't think that it's necessarily a mechanism by which the neurons control each other. We think that neurons may regulate themselves by regulating the expression of a number of different neurotransmitters and ion channels. So we're studying the mechanism by which the networks, the neurons themselves, regulate themselves.'

Dr. B:'Is it possible to inhibit the hippocampus and, in particular, GABAergic inhibitory neurons? Do we know what those neurons are? Do we know how many different inhibitory classes exist? Can we say that, well, we'll get to inhibition, because inhibition is a fundamental mechanism in the brain, and then we'll be able to control the hippocampus by inhibiting them? Is it possible?'

Dr. B:'It's not clear to you how inhibition can regulate neuronal activity in the hippocampus? What mechanism is there? What is the neuronal mechanism to inhibit? How does inhibition work? What is the physiological mechanism? What are the neuronal mechanisms for the hippocampus to inhibit its own activity? I mean, it is just not clear to me what inhibition means.'

Dr. M:'Well, as a matter of principle, they're supposed to be the negative poles of the network that produces excitatory networks. You know, if the excitatory neurons were positive in nature, then the inhibitory neurons would provide a negative signal to make things balance out. But you know, it's kind of like with the wind.'
Dr. B:'I mean, they can't work the way you described them.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, they have to be negative. Otherwise, they don't do anything.'
Dr. B:'But they just can't. They just can't.'
Dr. B:'And what is their function?'
Dr. M:'So their function is to inhibit. So it's to make things balance. Because you can't just get rid of them; you've got to have negative excitatory neurons. So that's their function.'
Dr. B:'Is that true?'

Dr. M:'Because, otherwise you're going to have these excitatory things all over the place. Otherwise they're just like you're trying to get rid of positive excitatory neurons, and then there'll be positive excitatory things everywhere. So there are limits.'
Dr. B:'But it has to be a negative.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory neurons are not supposed to have negative feedback. Instead, they work through inhibition of excitatory neurons. And inhibition is a positive force, as you will see later on in this conversation.'
Dr. M:'The inhibition is the function, it helps us to regulate the network.'
Dr. B:'What is the function? of inhibition?'
Dr. B:'Are we familiar with their physiology?'
Dr. B:'What does the inhibition serve to achieve?'
Dr. M:'It helps to regulate the network activity.'
Dr. B:'Is there any functional difference between pyramidal cells and inhibitory neurons? If so, is it worth the extra step of adding interneurons?'
Dr. M:'Well, pyramidal neurons are pyramidal neurons, and they can generate more action potentials, and then they can also act as inhibitory neurons, and they are in effect inhibitory neurons.'

Dr. B:'I'm sorry to interrupt, but there are so many variables. I mean, what do you expect to learn? What are the most important ones to control, and what is the least important? In other words, is there any way to control the brain activity without controlling any of these many parameters that affect brain activity? And this would still allow the brain activity to do what it's supposed to do, which is to make predictions and to make decisions.'
Dr. M:'That's where it comes to, to achieve a balance, where it allows us to regulate networks by changing and regulating the balance of neurotransmitter, and the strength of synaptic transmission.'
Dr. B:'Inhibition is what makes neural syntax so important.'
Dr. M:'It is.'
Dr. B:'Is there a special class of inhibition that you like to work with? Or are you willing to work with all types of inhibition?'
Dr. M:'Well, I am more interested in network dynamics, because that is what drives all our behaviour.'
Dr. B:'Do you have a prediction, what are the most promising directions for understanding the brain?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think my best work was probably done on invertebrates, like crabs and lobsters. So, we were able to study the function of individual neurons, and the roles of the different types of neurons, and the importance of these different modulatory neurons.'

Dr. B:'Inhibition is the most fundamental mechanism of neural coding. Do we have a general concept of what inhibition is? I mean, it's not only inhibition of excitation, but the absence of excitation... I mean, inhibition of inhibition is an important mechanism in the brain as well... I'm not sure that inhibition and excitation have a general concept.'
Dr. M:'Oh, no. I would say excitation is the most important...'
Dr. M:'...because they are a property of networks, not a property of neurons. It's a property of networks.'

Dr. B:'I agree, but we still have to look at how we use and how we understand them in isolation. The fact that inhibition is not only a property of networks does not mean that in isolation it doesn't have a lot of value. In isolation inhibition does not have much value, but when it's in the network it has a lot of value, because it controls the network and it gives us a framework in which to look for the function of networks.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are typically used in the generation of synchronous bursts, and the coordination of multiple neurons within networks requires that neurons can communicate with each other even while they are activated. We see that inhibitory neurons can be used in both synchronization and coordination, but not in all networks.'
Dr. B:'Why does inhibition not work well in some cases?'

Dr. M:'It's interesting that we didn't find any inhibition in the system of the pacemaker neuron. The pacemaker neuron is inhibited directly by the rhythmic action potentials in its network. The pacemaker is also inhibited indirectly by the rhythmic actions potentials in the inhibitory neurons and is, therefore, influenced by the rhythmic activation of the pacemaker neurons. The pacemaker neurons do not produce action potentials but instead have tonic spiking properties.'
Dr. M:' I see that there is another interesting example of a model neuron and how it relates to the synaptic interactions in the network.'
Dr. B:' What would the synaptic interactions be in the network without inhibition?'

Dr. M:' That's a good question. Well, there are two neurons in this model which are inhibitory neurons, and the synaptic connections between the two inhibitory neurons are inhibitory chemical synapses. The other is an electrically passive cell. And there are inhibitory chemical synaptic interactions between the electrically passive cell and the two inhibitory ones.'
Dr. M:' Well, I'm sure they would be there because synaptic interactions are important for neural circuit stability.'
Dr. B:' Are there any differences between the circuit with inhibition and the circuit without inhibition?'

Dr. M:' Yes, I see two different kinds of behaviors: one that is similar in terms of the network as a whole, and one that is very different. This is a model that is very robust against perturbations, and this is also known to occur with biological neurons.'
Dr. B:' And what are the differences between the circuit without inhibition and the circuit with inhibition?'

Dr. M:' This circuit is quite robust to perturbations, because, you know, this is a system that can compensate for a perturbation. You know, if there was a perturbation, you know, the circuit would still produce rhythmic activity.'
Dr. B:' Are inhibitory neurons important for circuit stability?'

Dr. M:' Of course, because when you're getting a circuit that doesn't work right, you know, you want to be able to identify the nodes that are going to fall off of that circuit, so that you can do some work to keep those neurons from falling off.'

Dr. B:' Is inhibition important for circuit stability? It seems to me that you may want to make a case, because it's not just that inhibition is important, but also there are other factors that come into play. What would the circuit be like if there were no inhibition? What would be the synaptic interactions in that case? What would be some of the synaptic interactions if inhibition was removed? What would be, you know, some of the synaptic dynamics that would result? What is your hypothesis?'

Dr. B:' I'm sure that you remember the old discussion about pyramidal cells and inhibitory interneurons? It's a little different now, but it's basically the same. So now the neuron is actually more sensitive to inhibition than to excitation. This is a new era, but the same kind of old questions.'

Dr. M:'Yes, of course. We also see that these neurons are very highly excitable, and this is a part of what gives them a strong influence on the network. So this is a very active part of my work now, in understanding the dynamic properties of these neurons in networks. What role do inhibitory neurons play in network dynamics?'

Dr. B:'So I'd like to add something about the role of interneurons. We're seeing now that inhibition has a very important role in controlling synaptic transmission, that is, the rate of neurotransmitter release. It is very important. I have been studying this for a long time, and I'm seeing now a real breakthrough. I'm a very happy person that my findings in this area are very well-supported.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, well the old questions are the more important ones, because they're still applicable. So when you're doing some experiments with a model neuron like that, you want to make sure that it shows different behaviors. Because it's not just a tool to find out how a network can work. It's also a tool to learn how neurons can function, or how neurons can function together.'

Dr. B:'I'm sure that it's not going to surprise the audience that you're in the audience that you know that there are a lot of different types of inhibition in the brain, but what is a simple description? I mean, one that people can use in a different context would be nice.'

Dr. M:'We tend to call the kind of inhibition, the inhibitory feedback, the feedforward inhibition. So we tend to think about feedback inhibition as something that happens at a later stage, but it's also an intrinsic inhibition. It's like the membrane potential, when you have a strong inward current, when you depolarize your membrane potential, you're also suppressing the potential of your membrane, so it's a feedforward effect.'

Dr. B:' Well, as you know, it's really hard to make the case of inhibition for network function in the brain, but I'll give it a shot. Inhibition is the most common mechanism for reducing population excitability, it's ubiquitous in neuronal circuits and it affects many more neurons than excitation.'
Dr. M:'Yes, and it's also a good thing, because it helps stabilize circuits in a way.'

Dr. B:' That's right, but in addition to stabilizing the network, inhibition also affects its timing and its probability of firing. Inhibition does not only serve to reduce activity but it also serves to bias the timing of neuronal activity. Inhibition is a dynamic, and in many brain regions its activity and timing is highly precise.'

Dr. M:' Oh yes, there are regions where neurons are inhibited as if by a circuit, so there are areas where these neurons are not active for days but the network is. In fact, the network is the one that is always active, but it's not being inhibited.'

Dr. B:' Exactly, and the network activity of the network is coordinated by these rhythms, but not by inhibition. These are the types of things that we are interested in. Let's go to the next point now.'
Dr. M:'We study them. We study the dynamic, the plasticity of networks.'

Dr. B:' You mean, what is plasticity? And what is dynamic? That is a bit different now, but let's move back to when the networks were already there. What would happen if the system were already there and then we'd have to study it in this way? What would happen, for example, if the hippocampus is already activated? Then we wouldn't need to go through it all and we would be able to make some quick assumptions.'

Dr. M:'I think it's important, because a lot of people think that when you get two neurons that are inhibited by each other, that is going to lead to some kind of a fight, whereas in fact, it does not necessarily lead to some kind off of a fight, it's not that two neurons that are mutually inhibitory can fight each other.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for neurons to not be mutually inhibitory? What is the function of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Well, as far as I'm concerned, you want to avoid mutual inhibition, because you want your neurons to be firing in a coordinated fashion and not, you want to prevent your neurons from firing one at a time.'

Dr. B:'So, so, this seems like the function of inhibition. So it seems like you would be able to make the case that inhibition is necessary to do what you want to do. Is that the case? Is that, is that the case?'

Dr. M:'Yes, so I think that the function of inhibition is actually pretty simple. So we think that we want our neurons to have their own specific patterns of activity that are important for us. So we want the neurons to fire out of a specific pattern of activity.'

Dr. B:'I have a question from a friend who's, who's, who would like to know, uh, if you would be able, uh, you know, uh, you would you be able to comment on that question, uh, how does a single neuron function? Is it like a, is it like a car, is it a car, is is it, is it like anything, is it like it's like a truck? What would it, what would it be?'
Dr. M:'You know, you want, you want to be sure, because, you know, you want to, you want to fire the specific kind of pattern that's needed.'

Dr. M:'Well, inhibition is not always the most effective way to control neuronal excitability, in fact, it's not even the most effective way. There are other modulatory neurons that can control neuronal activity.'
Dr. B:'What are they?'

Dr. M:'There are modulators that activate or inhibit a single neuron, that inhibit all the excitatory drive to that neuron, and you want that. But there are modulators that have multiple actions, they can act on multiple neurons at once. There are substances that activate neurons at the level of single cells, there are substances that act on networks of neurons at once.'
Dr. B:'And what are these substances? What are they?'

Dr. M:'Oh, it depends. One of the most obvious examples of this is hormones. Hormones are obviously important to reproduction, but they also regulate many things that are not immediately associated with reproduction. They also regulate muscle contraction, they regulate heart contraction. The heart itself is quite important, you know?'
Dr. B:'Where are those other inhibitory neurons?'
Dr. B:'But when it comes to the brain, these neurons are always first.'
Dr. B:'Is it possible that inhibitory neurons in the hippocampus have special control on other cells that is different from that of excitatory neurons?'

Dr. M:'Certainly. The neuron that controls the rhythmic behavior in the stomach is probably not necessarily inhibited by the neuron that controls the behavior in the mouth. The neuron that influences the muscle movements is probably not inhibited by the neuron responsible for the cardiac activity. So, in fact, there are two neurons that play quite disparate roles, and the roles that these neurons play in the system probably rely on different sets of chemical and electrical properties. And they probably utilize different sets of inputs.'
Dr. B:'But in the hippocampus, the interneuron network is an effective mechanism.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are the most important components of circuits in that their inhibitory actions are responsible for generating the temporal structure of circuits. Inhibitory neurons have a role in synaptic transmission and in the modulation of circuits.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory circuits are composed of inhibitory cells and excitatory circuits. In inhibitory circuits, there is no feedback from the inhibitory circuit. In inhibitory neurons, feedback inhibition is weak and often suppressed by the excitatory loop. In inhibitory cells, the inhibitory effect is mediated by the GABA A  receptor. In this mechanism, the effect of a neurotransmitter that binds to the receptor causes a hyperpolarization, and a decrease in excitation.'
Dr. M:'You might say that the function of inhibitors is to make a synaptic circuit, which generates a particular output.'

Dr. B:'The mechanism that enables the output is the excitatory action of the excitatory circuit. The inhibitory circuit has three elements: inhibitory neurons, which receive the output of the excit-atory circuit and act as gatekeepers; a second circuit, composed of the same neurons; and inhibitory interneurons, which act as the output of the circuit and act as'spike attenuators'.'
Dr. M:'To enable the inhibitory output.'

Dr. B:'That is an important aspect of inhibitory circuits. In order to make an inhibitory circuit, inhibitory cells must be interconnected. This is achieved by gap junctions between interneurons. It's also an important mechanism for transmitting inhibitory signals in the gamma frequency range, which is important for synchronizing principal cells, and is critical for providing the necessary strength of inhibition that is necessary to maintain the stability of circuit dynamics.'
Dr. B:'What do we know about the wiring of inhibitory neurons? How many inhibitory cell types are there?'

Dr. M:'As far as we know there is one neuron type that is a general modulator. There are many inhibitory neurons that are regulated by neuropeptides and there are many more that are regulated by neuromodulators that release small amines and small peptides. So there are several subtypes of inhibitory neuron that each have their own individual set of small molecule transmitters. The question is how many subtypes of inhibitors there are in the brain.'

Dr. M:'There are six identified inhibitory neurons that exist in the retina of the crustacean STG. Each of them is responsible for a different subset of the rhythmic circuit movements, like opening the stomach for feeding. We don't know the identity of the neurons that control the rhythmic circuit activity, but these six cell types are responsible for rhythmic patterns of the gastric mill, oesophageal, pyloric, cardiac, and pyloric rhythms.'

Dr. M:'We know, that there are many, many different kinds of inhibition that are going on in the brain. We know, for example, that one kind of inhibition is called long-term inhibition, where the inhibition occurs over seconds or minutes. Another kind of inhibition occurs over hours, days, and weeks. And yet another kind of inhibition is happening on milliseconds scales, and the dynamics of it is completely different.'
Dr. B:'Does the brain have a particular set of inhibitory cells, and if so what are their specific functions?'

Dr. M:'I don't know about wiring, but there are two classes of inhibitory neurons: neurons that fire tonically or intermittently, and oscillatory neurons that fire in a coordinated fashion to produce rhythms. There are neurons that respond to synaptic inputs, and then there are neurons that fire as a consequence of intrinsic membrane currents, and then there's a few other neurons that combine those two. So, yes, there are two types of inhibitory neurons.'
Dr. B:'And, are these types of inhibitory cells wired to each other? Are their axons collinear, or do we have to get there with a micro-drive to examine the wiring?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think they are wired, because it's been shown that their properties, their membrane potentials, their electrical synapses, depend on their wiring. So, I think that all the information that gets transmitted is dependent on the way in which the wiring of the neuron is set up. It is possible that different configurations could have led to different outcomes. We just don't know. We don't know which circuit, in all its complexity, would have developed.'

Dr. B:'If you're in a classroom, and you've a kid that's a little bit older, would it be easy to explain how inhibition is a critical ingredient of circuit function? What do we know about inhibition? How many different types of inhibition exist?'

Dr. M:'There are probably several cell types that are inhibitory, in terms of their voltage-gated conductance pattern and their connectivity. In that sense, their connectivity, they're all alike. The point I'm making is that there are a multitude of cell types that are known to be modulatory neurons and are themselves modulated by substances, and that those substances can alter the properties of those cells and that can change the circuits that they are responsible for generating.'

Dr. B:'Do we know that all inhibitory cells are also'modulatory neurons? Do inhibitory cells affect the activity of pyramidal cells in the same way? Are there mechanisms of inhibitory cell types that are different from pyramidal cells? Inhibitory cells are responsible for the temporal structure of circuit function but do they have other roles?'

Dr. M:'Well, some of the other roles they play, yes. One of the other functions they play is the modulation of circuits. There are neurons, for example, that release acetylcholine that can increase the amplitude of some currents. It can have a number of other functions as well, like increase the amplitude of the membrane current or increase the strength of synapses.'
Dr. M:'We know about about four or five different cell types of the inhibitory neurons in the network.'
Dr. B:'How many inhibitory interneuron types exist in the hippocampus and what is the relationship between these interneuron types? What are the inputs to these interneurons?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons provide inhibitory feedback to the central pattern generating networks which produce rhythms like the stomach rhythm, which is part of the pacemaker kernel of the pyloric circuit of the brain, which also contains a few other circuits like the stomatogastric circuit that generate the stomachs, the eyes and the heart of the animal. Those are all part of the pacemaking kernel of the central pattern generating network.'
Dr. B:'But I don't know if the inhibition is just one big kernel, and the entire brain is a giant oscillator. I can see that it is part of a much larger mechanism.'

Dr. M:'It is part of a larger network, but the important thing is that the central pattern generating circuits are highly connected to a variety of other circuits in the animal. They interact, but in all cases, the central pattern generating circuit is responsible for producing a stable rhythmic output that is not dependent on the interaction between the other circuits, but is highly dependent on the properties of the central pattern generator itself, and the properties of the neuron(s) in the central pattern generating group.'

Dr. B:'Then what does the other part of the brain do? I mean, what is the function of the excitatory part? We have to put together two parts that don't communicate with each other and produce an output, but I don't know what the function of that part is, if it is just random activity in the neocortex. What is the function of random activity? We have to answer that question.'

Dr. M:'The role of the neurons is to generate neural activity and to provide synaptic and intrinsic membrane properties to the network. It's a little bit of a conundrum. We know that neurons can respond to neuromodulators and that neurons can be active by themselves, and we know that they can interact with each other. They can interact with many other cells. They can generate a variety of motor patterns in many different ways. But the function of the neurons is really not to do something directly.'

Dr. M:'There's only one inhibitory neuron, you see, and it controls the activation of a specific kind of synapse in a network. That synapse, the activation of that synapse, is important for the activity of that network.'

Dr. B:'So there are some interneurons that are not part of that specific network, but they are activated by the activity of the network, and they control the activity of other interneurons in that network.'
Dr. M:'Exactly, yeah, and some of the control depends on the level of activity in the network, so they are part of the dynamics of the network.'
Dr. B:'I suppose we can call them regulators. And what is the function of regulators? They can make the neurons in that network to work in a particular manner.'
Dr. M:'Absolutely.'
Dr. B:'And if we understand the rules that govern those interneurons, we can understand the dynamics of that network. That's the process, right?'

Dr. M:'Yes, and when neurons get excited, it changes the way they conduct their activity, so they change their synaptic output, or they change their ionic channel expressions, their membrane conductances. And then it changes the activity of the neurons and therefore changes the activity of circuits.'

Dr. B:'Okay, but what is the physiological relevance of this? And the reason why we are discussing this? It seems very interesting that a circuit can work without its constituents, which are the interneurons and the excitatory neurons, but with a different output, but, uh, what I mean is, is that there's a functional difference between the two networks? So it would be interesting to know what is the physiological difference between the two network activities. What is the physiological difference?'

Dr. M:'Well, we have learned a lot from the work of the, of other scientists who have worked with rats and mice to work with the brain, and when you get down to the cellular level, you find that the neuronal networks are formed by different types of neurons. We don't know exactly what each neuron does, we know that each of these neurons has a particular set of synaptic connections, and each neuron has a set of ionic channels on its membrane.'

Dr. B:'And how do these things change when the network is excited? How do these things change? So, uh, so for example, if we can make the neurons that are in that circuit to fire synchronously, for a short period of time, you can say that they work as a unit. Now, this is one example, because when these interneurons fire together, the membrane conductance of the principal cells decreases.'

Dr. M:'Yes, for example, there's the pyloric and gastric mill networks that you find in the stomatogastric ganglion of the crab. There are these two distinct networks that are found within the same neuron, and they're activated by two distinct neuromodulatory inputs that are received by the neuron. And these neurons play a critical role in the generation of gastric mill and pyloric rhythms within the crab.'

Dr. B:'It is like a pacemaker mechanism, and the result of this is that the neurons in that network are excited and dis-inhibited by the activity of other neurons in that network. And this is how that network works together. And so this is what I'm asking. What is the function of all inhibitory neurons? Is it to allow this network to work together in a particular way, and in that case to stop the network from discharging, or is it to do something else?'
Dr. M:'It is to stop the network discharging, I'm afraid, and there are few examples of where this is the function of an inhibitory neuron.'

Dr. B:'Can you please explain this a little bit more, then, because these are not typical examples that are used in the literature? What is it like when these inhibitory cells stop network discharging? What is their output? What is their effect on other neurons in the network?'

Dr. M:'Well, their effect is that it stops the network from firing, and it actually does produce a tonic discharge in a circuit, because all of these circuits have one, and they can keep firing because they're just continuously, continuously firing. The only difference between the active state of the network and the quiescent state is that all of the active neurons that were firing are turned off during the quiescent states, and are turned on during the active state.'
Dr. B:'Is there a special type of inhibition that works like this? I'm not aware of such a mechanism.'
Dr. M:'Not that I'm aware of.'
Dr. M:'A number of studies in a number of preparations have shown that inhibition can be a regulator of circuit output, and that neurons can regulate circuit activity.'

Dr. B:'Who are they regulating? In which situations? Can they affect the output of a target neuron? If so, how do they affect their target? How do they affect circuit activity? What is the functional difference between inhibition and other physiological types of regulation? What is the advantage of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are widely distributed throughout the brain and are usually found in multiple cell types in each brain region. They do not normally control target neurons. Inhibition is used as a modulator in many neural circuits. They can either enhance the oscillation frequency of neurons in some networks (e.g., the gastric mill network of the crustacean stomatogastric nervous system), or decrease the oscillation frequency (e.g.'

Dr. B:'Are they special in any way? Are they unique? Can they affect a different way? Do they have special effects? How do they differ from other neurons? What is the effect of inhibition on network activity? Are there any special effects? What is the role of GABAergic interneurons? How does inhibition affect the output of the target neurons?'

Dr. M:'Many inhibitory neurons have properties that distinguish them from their modulator release counterparts. The inhibitory neurons themselves have at least one inhibitory transmitter, they themselves release inhibitory transmitters, and they can alter the properties of target neurons. The role of GABAergic neurons is very complicated, and a lot of studies have focused on its role in the pyloric network of the stomatogasts. In some networks, it is possible to study isolated GABAergic neurons.'

Dr. B:'Which neurons are inhibitory? How do they regulate circuit activity? How do they modify the output of their target neurons? What is their role? What is the difference between GABAergic interneuron and other forms of neurophysiological inhibition? What are the functional differences between inhibition and other types of regulation? How do they interact with their target? What is the influence of the inhibitory neuron on the output of their targets? What is the contribution of inhibition to circuit activity?'

Dr. M:'Excitatory neurons in the stomatogenetic ganglion release a single transmitter, glutamate, but excitatory neurons in other parts of the stomato-gastric nervous system release many additional transmitters (as well as a few that are not identified as excitatory, such as gamma-amino butyric acid).'

Dr. B:'Do inhibitory neurons contribute to the output of their neurons? Are there special effects? What are the mechanisms involved? Are there special mechanisms? Are there any unique effects? How do inhibitory neurons contribute toward network activity? Are they special in any other way? Can they affect their target neurons in a different way? Can they regulate circuit activity in a different manner? Can they have a different effect on the output of target neurons? What are the roles of GABAergic inter-neurons?'

Dr. M:'In general, neurons that release multiple transmitters have complex roles, because they can activate many target neurons, they can excite one or many, and they can influence many processes, or they can influence just one or two.'

Dr. M:'I think GABAergic interneuron activity is going to be one of the key issues, or areas that we should explore in our experimental neuroscience. GABAergic interneural activity is found in the central nervous system of most animals that have an anterior ganglia, so I think the nervous system of all animals. But it is seen in the nervous system of only some animals. And the extent to which it is found varies widely.'

Dr. B:'Is the role of GABA A  inhibition going to be different from the roles of other physiological mechanisms? In what ways? Is it different? What would we be looking at? Is it more important? Is it less important? What is the mechanism? Is it different from other modulatory mechanisms? What would we expect to find out? What would we like to learn? How would we test this? Are there any implications? How are we going to approach this?'
Dr. M:'These inhibitory neurons can be regulated to release GABA in specific circuits.'

Dr. M:'We study the dynamics of the pyloric network of the stomatogastric ganglion of the crab  Cancer borealis. We measure the time course of inhibitory synapses in the network and determine their functional significance to the network.'
